impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
The numbaNERDs Program measures several key aspects of Optimism Governance:

Grant Utilization: Tracking how funds are used by recipients and whether milestones are met, ensuring proper fund allocation.

Grants Misuse: Validating reports of misuse through the grants misuse reporting policy, ensuring accountability and corrective actions.

Contributor Validation: Ensuring data accuracy by having numbaNERDs validate key reports for governance decisions.

Governance Accountability: Monitoring protocol adherence to governance rules and enforcing consequences for violations.

Data Infrastructure: Building analytics infrastructure for various protocols, initially on OP Mainnet, and later expanding to early Superchain members.

These analytics strengthen transparency, accountability, and decision-making across Optimismâ€™s governance.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer: The numbaNERDs Program has significantly advanced governance-related analytics, data infrastructure, and transparency within the Optimism ecosystem, fostering growth and enabling informed decision-making. With 95 bounties completed and 3 grants misuse reports validated by numbaNERDs, the collective contributions of the numbaNERDs community have propelled Optimism's data infrastructure to excel beyond any other protocol in the blockchain ecosystem.

name: Voting-Bloc Entropy (VBE)
description:
We are a group of academic researchers who have devised Voting-Bloc Entropy (VBE, pronounced "vibe"), a new metric for decentralization in DAOs. We have worked collaboratively with the Optimism Foundation to provide a toolkit to measure VBE in both the Citizens House and Token House to study their levels of decentralization. We have also released a public dashboard measuring VBE across DAOs. (Optimism Collective, as it turns out, ranks #1, i.e., has the highest VBE.)

We can't build truly equitable and durable DAOs unless we understand the meaning of the 'D' in DAOâ€”the decentralization partâ€”and can measure it. Existing metricsâ€”the Nakamoto coefficient, the Gini coefficient, etc.â€”have a number of shortcomings. We have proposed a new metric, called voting-block entropy (VBE)â€”pronounced "vibe." It measures decentralization in a principled way that avoids the pitfalls of previous metrics and better reflects intuitive notions of decentralization, such as diversity of opinions, credible neutrality, etc.

VBE additionally offers practical guidance for DAO administrators and users. Using VBE as a theoretical foundation, we have proven a number of basic theorems about ways to increase VBE and thus improve decentralization. 

Our work on VBE has involved strong collaboration with the Optimism Foundation (OF). In consultation with the OF, we have developed tools for the OF (and other projects) for measuring VBE. We have shared the resulting code for the Optimism-specific VBE toolkit with the Optimism Foundation for their use in analysis of the Optimism DAOs. We have also created a public dashboard at https://tinyurl.com/y2ftwavu that includes up-to-date VBE measurements for a number of major DAOs in the ecosystem. (Optimism, as it turns out, is currently #1, i.e., exhibits the highest VBE.)

Our team consists of researchers associated with Ari Juels's group at Cornell Tech.

github.name: DAO VBE project GitHub repository
github.description:
This repository contains code for two elements of our project::

* DAO-VBE-Library: This repo is a quickstart to easily calculate the Voting-Bloc Entropy (VBE) metric on Optimism data, which showcases how decentralized voting blocs are in an organization (higher VBE = greater decentralization).

* oVBE Dashboard Code: This repository contains the code for the Observable Voting Bloc Entropy (oVBE) Dashboard, a tool for analyzing Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO) voting data.

links.name: DAO oVBE dashboard
links.description: This dasboard is a project by IC3 to provide transparency and visibility into DAO Voting-Bloc Entropy (VBE). The metrics for VBE stem from the paper by Austen et al. entitled "DAO Decentralization: Voting-Bloc Entropy, Bribery, and Dark DAOs" and available at https://arxiv.org/abs/2311.03530.

links.name: DAOs Need a Vibe Check
links.description: CoinDesk Opinion piece describing our work on VBE

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance
Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We formulated a new **measure of decentralization** that applies to the Optimism Collective's two houses and offers scientifically grounded **guidance** for improvement. This metric is called _voting-bloc entropy_ (VBE, pronounced "vibe"). It is being used for measurements in three ways:

* In close consultation with Optimism, we developed Optimism-specific **software tools** for measuring VBE that are now being used by the Optimism Collective to understand voting behaviors and Optimism governance more broadly. 
* We have launched a **public dashboard** that presents VBE measurements across the DAO ecosystem and includes Optimism and other leading DAOs. See https://t.co/2BqeTJtkNI. (Optimism is #1 by a nose, i.e., currently shows the highest VBE.)
* VBE is proving an **important metric** for DAO decentralization study, as highlighted by its inclusion in, e.g., a recent Optimism Foundation Mission Request (#183).

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
Beneficiaries of the three forms of measurement above include:

1. The **Gov Team at Optimism** helped shape the software tools to benefit from their use in analyzing past and future voting rounds (e.g., RetroPGF rounds), conducting experiments, and improving governance practices.
2. The **broad DAO and DeFi community** can now assess DAO decentralization across the ecosystem at a glance on our VBE dashboard---and the **Optimism Collective** benefits from showcasing of its strong commitment to and comparatively high degree of decentralization.
3. **Teams performing research** for the Optimism Collective benefit from a rigorous metric for decentralization and supporting Optimism-specific software tools.

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance
Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
Participation Rates: Tracking voter turnout and active participation over time, assessing how different types of proposals impact engagement.

Proposal Success Rates: Analyzing the approval and rejection rates of proposals, identifying which categories (e.g., upgrades, funding) see the highest success.

Delegate Influence: Measuring the voting power and influence of top delegates, and how their votes sway proposal outcomes.

Governance Token Distribution: Assessing the decentralization of OP tokens, monitoring whether governance power is becoming more concentrated or dispersed.

Proposal Performance & Impact: Evaluating the success of initiatives funded through governance and their benefit to the ecosystem.

Transparency & Accountability: Auditing the execution of proposals to ensure funds are used as intended and decisions are clearly communicated.

These metrics ensure Optimism's governance is effective, transparent, and decentralized.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
The primary beneficiaries of my analytics work in Optimism Governance are:

Governance Participants (Token Holders and Delegates): Data on participation rates, proposal success, and delegate influence help them make informed decisions.

Example: Delegates can see how their votes align with community sentiment and adjust.

Optimism Collective: Insights improve governance, decentralization, and voter turnout.

Example: Identifying participation gaps and refining proposals.

Project Teams & Proposal Creators: Analytics show which proposals succeed, helping teams craft better proposals.

Example: A technical upgrade proposal can be tailored based on past successes.

Governance Researchers: They benchmark governance and track trends.

Example: Comparative studies on governance decentralization.

Optimism Ecosystem: Transparency and data-driven insights improve governance, fostering trust and stability.

These insights lead to informed decisions, better participation, and accountability.

name: Collective Feedback Commission [Token House]

Our input helps refine processes and governance proposals, ensuring a more resilient system as the Collective takes on greater responsibilities

subcategory: Councils, Commissions and Advisory Boards; NERD programs focused exclusively on core governance responsibilities (GovNERDs)::This includes Security Council, Grants Council, Developer Advisory Board, Code of Conduct Council, Anticapture Commission, Collective Feedback Commissions and GovNERDs.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 6: May 9th - September 18th 2024 (up until Voting Cycle #28)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The mandate of the Token House Collective Feedback Commission (CFC) is to formalize the process of gathering high-context feedback from engaged community members during the design phase, rather than after designs are finalized. By consulting the Foundation on early-stage drafts, we ensure that input from top delegates and governance leads directly shapes decisions as they are being developed. CFC members provided feedback on any drafts shared by the Optimism Foundation. This approach marks a significant first step toward deeper community involvement in the governance design process, aligning with the long-term goal of increased community ownership. 

More details can be found here:
- Introducing the Collective Feedback Commission
https://gov.optimism.io/t/introducing-the-collective-feedback-commission/7863
- The Path to Open Metagovernance
https://gov.optimism.io/t/the-path-to-open-metagovernance/7728

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
The CFC Token House achieved its mandate by providing high-context feedback on 15 documents during Season 6, aligning with the Optimism Foundation's goal of reducing dependency on the Foundation in governance design. 

Key impacts include:
- Eliminated Trust Tiers from Season 6 grant applications.
- Implemented a 72-hour response SLA for the Developer Advisory Board (DAB).
- Clarified retro reward eligibility and expanded â€œstakeholdersâ€ scope.
- Strengthened Chain Delegation Program with clearer criteria.
- Refined the Superchain strategy, leading to the Vision AMA.

Based on this success, the Commission will continue into its next iteration. More details here:
https://gov.optimism.io/t/collective-feedback-commission-pilot-retrospective/8970

Reward split:
The rewards split for CFC members was based on the number of reviews each completed.
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Ptp8e3G5IfJi62aStBjOvNoJnH69glley_qWa3L6j-0/edit?usp=sharing

name: Mission Request Workshop
description:
Hello I am Jesse (Jrocki), I currently serve on the Grants Council for season 6 and I am applying for Retro Funding for a smol Mission Request Workshop I hosted at the start of season 6. It should be noted that this was just one workshop held at the start of season 6.

The goal of the workshop was to take participants through the process of brainstorming ideas for mission requests, expanding on one of those ideas then begin forming it into a mission request. In short giving participants the right context and tools required for writing their own mission request to post for sponsorship.

links.name: Mission Request Workshop Figma Board
links.description:
During the Workshop we used this Figma Board to brainstorm Mission Request ideas together. We then grouped those ideas into common themes. The most common theme was "Real World Payment Use Cases" so we then expanded upon this idea with the common goal to answer the Mission Request Template Questions.

After the Workshop I posted the ideas generated from the Workshop on the governance forum here for the community to use:
https://gov.optimism.io/t/intent-3-mission-request-sponsorships/8405/10?u=jrocki

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
The Mission Request Workshop helped facilitate the brainstorming of ideas as well as how to form those ideas into a Mission Request for Season 6.

Here are some highlights of the ideas generated from the Mission Request Workshop which were then posted to the forum:
- Bring developers to the Superchain by bootstrapping real-world payment ecosystems
- Bring developers to the Superchain by encouraging experimental projects with micro-grants
- Bring developers to the Superchain by facilitating easier tools to develop new products

Full list can be viewed here on the forum:
https://gov.optimism.io/t/intent-3-mission-request-sponsorships/8405/10?u=jrocki

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
The impact of this workshop and posting these ideas to the forum is open to interpretation but you can view the final list of Mission Requests for season 6 here:  
https://app.charmverse.io/op-grants/mission-request-list-23238814302303523

And you can track the conversations had on the forum (link above) after the ideas from the workshop were posted here: 
https://gov.optimism.io/t/intent-3-mission-request-sponsorships/8405/10?u=jrocki

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer: Lawyerd's platform empowered the Optimism community to report scams, fraud, and brand violations, significantly improving transparency and accountability within the ecosystem. By integrating with the OP Stack, Lawyerd enabled more efficient community-driven governance, allowing participants to flag violations, protect their favorite projects, and earn rewards for contributing to ecosystem safety. Our platform actively supported decentralized governance by reducing fraud and scams that harm community trust, making Optimism a safer and more secure environment for builders and users alike.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?

Developers benefit from reduced risks of scams undermining their projects, and brands are better protected against counterfeiters. Community members benefit by being incentivized to participate actively in governance by reporting violations, thereby creating a safer and more transparent environment across the Optimism ecosystem.

name: Badgeholder Sessions
description:
The Badgeholder Sessions are mainly in-person gatherings hosted to introduce new tools connected to RetroRounds. In these sessions Badgeholders can provide feedback to teams building governance infra to inform their evolution and end-state.

In this project the following sessions are included:
- 3 List making sessions during R3
- In-person onboarding session for Badgeholders at ZuConnect
- In-person workshop session with Badgies at EthDenver

This work is not supported by grants or any other type of funding from presenting teams or the Collective beyond Retro Funding.

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
Each Badgeholder session has had a different focus given that the needs are matched according to the stage of RetroRounds and the current experiments being carried out:

1. Workshops on the creation of lists for 3 different categories prior to RetroRound3. I designed and ran the workshops in a couple of them with the support of 2 other Badgeholders.
2. Istanbul Meetup @ Onchain Summit where we gathered to 1) connect, 2) explore thoughts on lists and voting, 3) learn about projects such as Pairwise. Secured a place with the OP team, created merch, and coordinated with Badgeholders attending DevConnect. 
3. Badgies Workshopping @ Eth Denver: Coordinated the event, contacted the presenting teams, and led the session.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
Each session has led to different improvements in the process and experiments of RetroRounds. 
For the first two, the outcomes are described above. 

For the 3 Session, here is some additional information:

In this session the following teams presented and received feedback from Badgeholders and the Foundation:
1. EZKL - https://retrofunding.ezkl.xyz/
2. Buidl Guild - Metrics Based Voting
3. Agora 
4. Pairwise
5. EasyRPGF

 This session particularly informed changes in the design of voting for Round 4, the release of EZKL's proving system for Retro3 results, among other things.

name: Grant Round Analysis (S5R2)
description:
This was a one of project I executed to explore the efficacy of how grants were scored during S5 R2 

https://gov.optimism.io/t/grants-season-5-round-2-data-analysis/8169

links.name: Forum Post
links.description: Surfaced method and process in analysing the data.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We wanted to understand the rounds scoring mechanism given the totals and numbers reported did not make sense as an applicant.

In our round analysis. We extracted the raw excel data and and transformed them into formats typically used in data science (machine learning).

In doing so we were able to create a visual representation of the scoring for the round. We uncovered (known) shortcomings of the platform and were able to provide the collective information in an easy to understand format.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
I would say OP grants the lead Gonna.eth. After sharing my analysis, this led to a couple of initiatives that were since implemented in later rounds.

* Sharing anon scores against each rubic
* Making the individual reviewers scores public

My work was also referenced to support another members claim in the more topics ([Mission Request] Optimism Dominance in Yield-Bearing Assets (3 of 4) category) 

Which was super cool to see.

https://gov.optimism.io/t/mission-request-optimism-dominance-in-yield-bearing-assets-3-of-4/8440/22?u=1a35e1

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The Retro Funding 3 Voting App (https://vote.optimism.io/retropgf/3) provided the voting interface for Retro Funding 3. It displayed 600+ projects who applied for the round, and let citizens peruse profits and create and submit their ballot. It was one of the two official voting UIs for this round.

Retro Funding 3 was the largest ever single round in terms of both funding allocation and number of applicants. This round was uniquely enabled by transitioning from spreadsheets to this application. 

Many voters spend days filling their ballot with hundreds of projects using this app due to the sheer scale of this round.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
At BAG, our mission is to help people learn about and engage with Optimism. We do this by making Optimism Governance accessible to all. Hereâ€™s how we support it:

Education:
We provide simple guides on how Optimism Governance works, including voting on Snapshot and understanding decision-making.

Community Engagement:
BAG is a platform for discussing governance proposals, sharing opinions, and understanding how decisions impact the future of Optimism.

Voting Awareness:
We keep members informed about voting deadlines and proposals, ensuring they have the tools to cast their votes on Snapshot.

Workshops and Events:
We host events to educate members on governance topics, Retroactive Public Goods Funding (RetroPGF), and how to contribute.

Showcasing Impact:
We highlight the importance of public goods funding and guide members on supporting these initiatives through governance.

By educating and engaging our community, BAG ensures more people take part in shaping the future of Optimism.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Hereâ€™s a slightly shorter version:

The people who have benefited most from BAG's infrastructure are:

Newcomers to Optimism:
Our educational resources help individuals new to Optimism and Web3 by simplifying governance, voting, and public goods funding, making it easy for beginners to engage.

Active Community Members:
Engaged participants benefit from discussions on proposals and staying informed about voting, enabling them to actively shape Optimism's future.

Project Developers and Creators:
Builders who contribute to public goods benefit from our focus on RetroPGF and governance, as we help the community understand the impact of these projects.

Web3 Enthusiasts:
Web3 enthusiasts interested in decentralized governance find BAG's resources essential in navigating Optimism and participating effectively.

name: Syntra
description:
Syntra is a delegate dashboard that simplifies DAO governance by streamlining drafting, decision-making, and management with calendar integration.

In the evolving world of decentralized governance, DAOs have become central to decision-making across Web3. Yet, for many delegates, the tools and processes available often feel fragmented, isolated, and hard to navigate. Weâ€™ve experienced these challenges firsthand, not just as developers but as participants in various DAOs.

Syntra is a delegate dashboard born from this realization: governance doesnâ€™t need an isolated toolâ€”it requires an integrated solution focused on people, the ones driving these organizations forward.

Shift in Focus: From Tools to People

For too long, DAO tooling has been focused on solving specific issuesâ€”one tool for proposals, another for voting, and yet another for analytics. The result? A fragmented experience that leaves participants, both newcomers and experienced teams, struggling to piece together a coherent workflow.

Our Approach

We knew there had to be a better way, so we asked: What if we could give DAO participants a head start? What if we could streamline these processes, so they can focus on what really mattersâ€”making impactful decisions?. Our target user base varies from newcomers to professional delegates leading teams of 10+ members.

For newcomers: Syntra lowers the barriers to entry, making it easier to draft proposals, post comments, participate in discussions, vote, and analyze governance activity.
For professional organizations: It facilitates coordination and collaboration, providing role-based access and tracking tools to streamline internal processes.
By integrating many of the existing tools within the DAO ecosystem, we help delegates manage governance processes more efficiently, improving not just individual contributions but also team-based workflows.

links.name: Syntra
links.description:
Starting from the final MVP release, the project will be open-source. It is not intended for profit, as it is a public good. The announcement will be made in the forum communication thread:
https://gov.optimism.io/t/request-for-feedback-syntra-setting-a-new-standard-for-dao-participation/8878

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Syntra simplifies key governance tasks for OptimismDAO Delegates, improving efficiency and decision-making. It also helps with the onboarding of new participants lowering the barrier to entry.

"### **A Day in the Life of an OptimismDAO Delegate with Syntra**

- ***Efficient Proposal Creation***
	- *Delegates start their day by accessing a user-friendly dashboard and draft manager.*
	- *They can quickly draft proposals and use templates, cutting proposal creation time by 50%.*
- ***Informed Decision Making***
	- *Syntra provides an overview of updated resources, ensuring delegates have all necessary context at their disposal.*
	- *Integration with OptimismDAO's calendar helping delegates stay up to date with community calls, office hours and seasons timelines.*
- ***Cross-DAO Management***
	- *For delegates involved in multiple DAOs, Syntra provides a unified interface without the need of switching between platforms. This also lower the barrier to entry of external DAO actors*"

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Syntra contributed to Optimism Governance since its  **private alpha release in late August**  and  **public alpha release in early September**.

## Users:
### OptimismDAO delegates
-   **Newcomers**: Syntra lowered barriers to entry by simplifying proposal drafting, commenting, voting, and governance analysis.
-   **Professional teams**: It streamlined internal coordination with role-based access and tracking features.

As of October 8th, Syntra has:

-   **209 total logins**
-   **33 MAU**: 33 active Optimism sessions since Sept (Month to date). 
	- **Active**: at least 1 Draft created.
-   OP delegates from  **5 different countries** to date.
-   Currently also being used by SEEDGov for drafting.

More information regarding activity is available in the [Google Drive link](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1TZWtb_Q67hwqBHNGpgT4V7HocAs1LNKT?usp=sharing).

name: EVM Explorer
description: We are excited to introduce EVM Explorer, a powerful, open-source web interface designed to streamline the exploration and analysis of blockchain data across multiple EVM chains, including the Optimism ecosystem. EVM Explorer utilizes the BlockScout API and viem library to enable users to delve into transaction patterns, user behavior, and smart contract data, providing a versatile tool for efficient and insightful blockchain exploration.

github.description: EVM Smart Contract Explorer. Discover and track EVM smart contract data.

links.name: [Discussion] On-chain Builders Delivering Metrics Data

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more
Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
EVM Explorer's analytics work provides valuable insights into the influence of smart contract behavior on governance processes, enhancing transparency and understanding of the impact of smart contracts on Optimism Governance.

Smart Contract Performance: Analyzing the performance and usage of smart contracts within the Optimism network to understand their impact on governance processes. This includes tracking metrics such as the number of interactions with specific contracts, the frequency of transactions, and the distribution of contract usage across different governance-related functions.

Governance-relevant Token Balances: Tracking and analyzing token balances that are relevant to governance, such as voting tokens or tokens used for delegating authority. This analysis sheds light on the distribution of voting power, governance-related events, and stakeholder engagement in governance decision-making.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer: The analytics work by EVM Explorer on smart contract behavior in Optimism Governance benefits various ecosystem stakeholders. Active governance participants gain insights into smart contract performance and token balances, aiding informed decision-making and effective participation. Governance teams leverage detailed analytics to assess governance mechanisms, identify areas for enhancement, and tailor strategies. Developers benefit from understanding user interactions with contracts, leading to improved contract efficiency. Token projects find value in analytics on token balances and distribution for assessing engagement and governance mechanisms. Researchers benefit from comprehensive analytics, deepening insights into governance processes and contributing to the governance community. Overall, EVM Explorer's analytics enhance transparency, understanding, and efficiency in Optimism Governance, benefiting stakeholders across the ecosystem.

name: Ethereum Nigeria
description:
Ethereum Nigeria is a decentralized community focused on promoting the development and adoption of Ethereum and blockchain technologies across Nigeria


Mission:
We are dedicated to fostering blockchain education, innovation, and community development across Africa. Our mission is to accelerate the adoption of decentralized technologies and empower individuals and organizations to harness the benefits of blockchain for social and economic progress. As advocates for transparency, inclusivity, and sustainability, we are focus on the values and goals of the Optimism Collective.

Core Focus Areas:

Education and Awareness: We host educational events, workshops, and conferences that bring together blockchain enthusiasts, developers, and industry leaders to share knowledge and insights about decentralized technologies.
Community Development: By organizing initiatives like Lagos Blockchain Week, the Base Onchain Buildathon, ETHNigeria Hackathon (in-view) we create spaces where blockchain communities can collaborate, innovate, contribute and thrive.

links.description: Buildup to ETH Nigeria Hackathon and Onchain Summer Work report

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
During this period, we introduced decentralized voting and analytics tools that have made governance processes more accessible and transparent. These tools empowered community members to actively participate in governance, which helped increase the number of informed and engaged participants within the OP ecosystem. The workshops and interactive sessions held during these events also provided a platform for new governance leaders to emerge, which has contributed to a more diverse and resilient governance structure.

We gathered valuable feedback and insights from participants, which we analyzed and shared with the  community. This data has informed the ongoing development and refinement of OP governance frameworks, supporting greater accountability and responsiveness within the governance processes. By actively involving the community in this period, our projects have helped lay a stronger foundation for a collaborative and adaptive governance environment on Optimism.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
Our facilitation work during Lagos Blockchain Week and the Base Onchain Buildathon has progressively improved the performance of governance processes by introducing tools and gathering insights that make governance more inclusive, transparent, and efficient. With the hackathon projects on beta, participants will have more accessible means to engage with governance, fostering greater understanding and involvement.

As we continue gathering feedback and refining these tools, we are actively contributing to the evolution of Optimism's governance frameworks. This ongoing process enables us to identify and address governance challenges in real time, which gradually enhances accountability and responsiveness. By iterating on these insights, we are moving towards a more data-driven governance environment that aligns better with community needs, ultimately contributing to a more dynamic and effective governance structure within Optimism.

links.name: Optimism Governor

An Optimism network-based modular system of Governor contracts allows deployment of on-chain voting protocols similar to Compoundâ€™s Governor Alpha & Bravo and beyond. This is the Boardroom Governor integration, where any developer can interact with various governance protocols and data sources in a flexible and extensible manner.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Increased Participation:
The initial support for Snapshot proposals and early onchain delegations, and the subsequent onchain integration has expanded the avenues for community participation. By offering an alternative to vote.optimism.io, we've broadened the choices available to voters, driving higher engagement in governance processes.

Standardized Governance Experience:
By integrating the entire Optimism governance stack, Boardroom has provided a consistent and user-friendly governance experience for developers accessing standardized data and governance interactions via our APIs and SDK.  

Informed Community:
Our "Weekly Recaps" initiative has ensured that the Optimism community remains updated on key governance activities.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: Governance participants across the Optimism ecosystem, including both token holders and delegates, have benefited most from Boardroomâ€™s infrastructure and tooling. Delegates can make more informed decisions using real-time data from Boardroomâ€™s integrated API and SDK. Additionally, token holders benefit from alternative voting platforms and more streamlined processes, increasing their participation in governance. Developers, too, experience improved workflows through standardized governance interactions, ensuring smooth operations across the Optimism stack.

name: Curia OP Governance Analytics Dashboard
description:
We are the team behind the Curia OP Governance Analytics Dashboard, a comprehensive tool designed to empower the Optimism Collective through transparency and data-driven insights. Our dashboard provides essential governance metrics such as participation rates, voting power distribution, delegates' performance, and voting history. By continuously refining our features based on community feedback, we've enriched stakeholder engagement and informed decision-making processes.

Since last year, we've introduced significant enhancements to the dashboard, including:

Citizen House Integration: We now provide comprehensive data visualization tools for the Citizen House, focusing on Badgeholder analytics and veto proposals. This update enables a clearer understanding of activities within the Citizen House and enhances transparency around proposal results and participation.

RetroPGF Project Analytics: Our dashboard now offers detailed tracking and insights into RetroPGF projects, including an Application Funnel Overview that displays the entire project application process, from submission to decision. We also provide analytics on ongoing and upcoming RetroPGF projects, including RetroPGF 3 & 4, ensuring that the community can better understand and monitor project dynamics and impact.

UI and User Experience Improvements: We revamped the user interface, enhancing the visibility of delegate voting power and improving the navigation bar for easier interaction. Our new delegate card feature allows for more detailed and interactive insights, making it easier for users to track individual delegate activity.

Partial Delegation Integration: We introduced detailed insights into the sources of a delegate's voting power, distinguishing between partial and full delegations. This feature provides a more granular view of each delegateâ€™s influence within the governance process.

Delegate Ranking Bump Chart: A dynamic tool that visualizes the evolution of delegatesâ€™ voting power over various timeframes, offering a detailed view of ranking changes to better understand the governance dynamics.

Through these updates, the Curia OP Governance Analytics Dashboard has continued to foster a culture of accountability, transparency, and informed governance across the Optimism Collective, empowering stakeholders to make astute, data-driven decisions.

This resulted in the Optimism Foundation adjusting their criteria and calculations to ensure accuracy and fairness in delegate recognition.

name: Superfluid
description:
Superfluid is the leading asset streaming protocol that brings reward distributions like airstreams, vesting and team compensation to DAOs and crypto-native businesses worldwide.

The protocol has been live on Optimism since March 2022 and on Base since July 2023. It has been empowering developers with a crypto-native financial primitive, money streaming, and a modular smart contracts framework to build applications that leverage a formula-based balance and gasless, liquid, ongoing value transfer.

Over 49,394 streams have been started on Optimism and 644,584 on Base for a combined total volume of over $280M.

Superfluid is designed to minimize its TVL in favor of making assets available to sender or recipient at all times, minimizing funds locked in smart contracts. As such its impact is better measures in total volume transferred, number of total or active streams, total number of users and daily active users. When measuring the protocol activity it's important to not only rely on the on-chain transaction to smart contracts, but also on the the inner mechanics of the protocol (i.e. by evaluating the actions triggered via callData or by using the protocol subgraph).

On the alignment with Optimism and Retro Funding
- Superfluid is builder-centric. A developer tool with clear focus on onboarding more developers to build more apps. As such, itâ€™s additive to Optimismâ€™s own goals.
- Superfluid is supporting long term, real world use cases, like Salaries, Subscriptions, Memberships, Rentals, Airdrops, Grants distribution as well as entirely novel applications in DeFi, SocialFi and beyond.

Superfluid Protocol has been used by the Optimism Foundation to stream the RPGF3 & RF4 grants, and will be used again in the upcoming rounds, providing the rails for a seamless funds distribution.

The protocol has been designed around builders and developers, with a set of tools available for building, debugging and data retrieval that empower new applications development. Here you can see an overview of projects built on Superfluid that have added value (and usage) to the Optimism and Base networks: https://www.superfluid.finance/post/how-superfluid-protocol-is-empowering-onchain-builders

If you have any questions or would like to learn more about Superfluid, please reach out to mdali.eth on Warpcast or Twitter/X.

ventureFunding.details: Superfluid received a total of $14.1M in venture funding since Jan 2020, here you can find the latest fundraising announcement: https://www.superfluid.finance/post/superfluid-secures-usd5-1m-to-boost-growth

grants.details:
Superfluid received 150k OP grant from Optimism Collective Governance Fund Phase 1, the funds were allocated to community projects and were not used directly by Superfluid.
https://www.superfluid.finance/post/announcing-the-recipients-of-our-superfluid-builder-grants-for-optimism

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Superfluid Protocol was used to distribute RPGF3 and RF4 grants, streaming over 32M OP to 900+ projects in the industry to date (RF4 streams are still ongoing).

The Superfluid Dashboard substantially improved the grants claim and management UX for recipients while allowing better funds distribution monitoring and management for the Optimism team. 

Recipients were also able to redirect streams to their team members ensuring they got paid in real-time as funding was being paid out by Optimism.  

You can read more about the improvements enabled by Superfluid here:
RPGF3 - https://medium.com/superfluid-blog/optimism-selects-superfluid-for-rpgf3-grants-streaming-612c37ecc89c
RF4 - https://medium.com/@superfluid_HQ/optimism-is-streaming-rf4-grants-with-superfluid-1835182bf18b

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Prior to the introduction of Superfluid Protocol in the retro funding process grant recipients had to claim their funds via direct interaction with Optimism's smart contracts, mostly by using the block explorer interface to make a contract call.

With the introduction of Superfluid recipients can see the total amount of OP awarded to them and the detailed timeline of the grant payout. They can also manage their incoming stream by redirecting it (or splitting it) to team members, third parties or DeFi apps in real time. You can read more about stream redirection and splitting here: https://help.superfluid.finance/en/articles/8907702-how-to-split-your-incoming-rpgf-grant

Superfluid also enabled smooth funds distribution, management and control for the Optimism team.

The entire community could benefit from transparent and easy to understand funding process, timeline and status (i.e. https://dune.com/0xkhmer/retropgf-3).

name: DeepDAO
description:
DeepDAO aggregates comprehensive data on the Optimism Collective, as well as 296 other DAOs on optimism mainnet. Our industry-leading dashboard surfaces insights on: 

- OP Collectiveâ€™s DAO treasury (including treasury assets, trends, and contracts), 
- OP Collectiveâ€™s governance (including various voter and proposal activity metrics and trends), 
- OP Collectiveâ€™s delegation ecosystem (including top active delegates and badgeholders),
- OP Collectiveâ€™s governance centralization through coalitions analysis,
- OP Collectiveâ€™s governance resilience by analyzing the impact of token price on governance. 
- OP Collectiveâ€™s voter participation in other DAOs, enabling marketing insights, and voter groups such as loyal voters, missing voters.

DeepDAO dashboards have been live for over 4 years, and we have been providing comprehensive and free-to-access DAO data to all participants in the OP Collective from day one. DeepDAO data is widely used in academic research, crypto and mainstream media. 

Our efforts have made the Optimism DAO ecosystem healthier, transparent and widely appreciated.
pricingModelDetails: DeepDAO is about to start selling subscriptions to Pro DAO dashboards. The cost will be 3k-5k a month. The Optimism Pro version is available to the community for free. DeepDAO also sells data API for academics and research institutes.

links.name: Optimism Collectiveâ€™s PRO dashboard on DeepDAO
links.description:
This is the most comprehensive source of truth on Optimism at the moment. It covers the OP Collective from all angles - treasury, token, votes, delegates, delegate coalitions, and place in the ecosystem. Each tab (you can click between them) includes multiple graphs and metrics, providing a nuanced look into the Collectiveâ€™s inner workings. Below we have given short description to the sections of this dashboard, to fully illustrate its capabilities.

Note that the entire dashboard is free for everyone. 

Treasury
The treasury analysis provides a deeper look into what is going inside the Collectiveâ€™s treasury. Starting with treasury change over time, it also lists the treasury currencies, and assets. Scrolling down, you can find a treasury composition percentage graph, a month by month total treasury value, and a list of all contracts related to the OP Collective. The contracts are labeled with the appropriate tags (liquid funds, protocol funds, governor, etc.)  

Token
Token analysis correlates the performance of the governance token ($OP) to governance metrics. The graphs of token price vs successful proposals, and average votes per proposal, help gauge governance sentiment and device plans to ensure a resilient voter set despite market conditions. This tab also includes a list of all DAOs holding the OP token in their treasury. 

Voter Trends
This tab provides deep insights on voter activity by tracking participation in various timeframes, and types of activity (proposals, avg. votes per proposals, and move). One can see how the total number of votes, voters, and average votes per proposal have changed over the past 3 years. The tab also provides analysis in shorter time frames over the past year, helping the Collective easily measure the impact of community and governance initiatives. 

Delegates
This is one of the most important sections of OP Collectiveâ€™s PRO dashboard. Starting with a table on governance commitment - the tab displays delegates based on their number of delegators, voting power, and recent activity. Then it provides a comprehensive list of the most influential addresses in OP Collective, including delegates, badgeholders, and other stakeholders. What is proprietary and unique to DeepDAO is the historical governance profile for each of these addresses. Clicking on any of these profiles takes one to their profile page on DeepDAO, which displays their aggregate governance activity across the entire DAO ecosystem.  

Delegate Coalitions
Together with the delegates dashboard, the Coalitions dashboard provides a look at the people (addresses) that frequently vote together, and their combined power. This is a useful tool for understanding, and acting on the state of power concentration among the collective delegates - beyond any one individual. If one truly wants to know who are the influential delegates, the Coalitions dashboard is the place to look at. 

Ecosystem
The Ecosystem tab (scroll right to find it) provides insights on the place of the collectiveâ€™s voters and delegates in the entire DAO ecosystem. It maps voters' interests in DAO sectors (as categorized by DeepDAO), and voters' engagement with other DAOs - the collectiveâ€™s competitor, and partner DAOs. These insights provide a larger view on where the collective is, and has the power to feed into the collective's marketing initiatives.

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance
Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
DeepDAO provides the most comprehensive analysis of different components of Optimism governance:

- Treasury, including trends over time, tokens, assets and composition (OP vs stables, majors, and others).

-  Token, including governance performance influence on the OP token price.

- Voter Trends: multiple metrics of quality and intensity of governance participation in the Collective. Successful proposals, avg. votes per proposal, and others, in multiple timeframes. We also categorize voters based on their governance score to understand participant quality.

- Delegation, including intensity, and quantity of involvement across voting power, delegators, total votes, and voting periods.

- Delegate Coalitions, tracking governance activity of power groups of up to 6 addresses. Together with Delegation, this provides deep analysis of decentralization within Optimism governance.

- Voters Ecosystem, measuring the Collective voters involvement in other DAOs, including competing DAOs.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
New Participants: DeepDAO helps new entrants to the DAO ecosystem discover the OP Collective, ensuring they do not face information asymmetry compared to experienced participants.

Delegates use DeepDAO to stay updated on OP Collective activities. Our analytics dashboard offers extensive information on the DAO's well-being.

Builders: DeepDAO makes it easy for builders to identify and approach the right delegates for feedback. (using the Delegation, and Coalitions dashboards).

Tooling Providers: DeepDAO aggregates information across various tooling providers and includes a tools page listing all DAO tools available to the Optimism Collective.

OP Collective: Our data on coalitions, governance segmentation and voter trends provides multiple indicators of the DAOâ€™s decentralization, governance resilience and security. The Collective benefits immensely from a free resource like DeepDAO.

Investors, journalists, researchers: 1000s of media articles and academic papers quote DeepDAO data.

name: Farcaster Attestation
description:
Farcaster Attestation is bringing Farcaster wallet verification on-chain to the Optimism Mainnet. Traditionally, Farcaster wallet verification data is only accessible through the Farcaster Hub, which cannot be utilized directly on Optimism Mainnet via Solidity smart contracts. This creates a centralization issue in the Retro Funding EAS schema, limiting the authorized attester to a single wallet, as it requires verification from a centralized backend.

Farcaster Attestation resolves this centralization problem by enabling anyone to attest their Farcaster data permissionlessly.

We have replicated the Retro Funding Project and Metadata Schema to test the integration with Farcaster Attestation. For more information, refer to the Links section.

subcategory: Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer: Did you know that the Retro Funding application process is currently centralized and relies on trust in the application UI provider (Agora)? This is because there is no way to verify the relationship between a wallet address and a Farcaster ID on-chain. Farcaster Attestation solves this by enabling the verification of wallet addresses and Farcaster IDs on Optimism Mainnet, making the Retro Funding application process decentralized and permissionless.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The Optimism Foundation has benefited from Farcaster Attestation for decentralizing the Retro Funding EAS Schemas, making them permissionless.

Governance tooling builders gain from the permissionless Retro Funding EAS Schema, powered by Farcaster Attestation, as it allows anyone to build project management and application UIs for Retro Funding, not just Agora.

This opens the door to many creative ideas in the Retro Funding space.

impactStatement.answer:
In collaboration with OSO, Passport XYZ's Humanity scores were used to better understand the likelihood of real humans that were interacting with projects over the last year. The goal was to determine which projects were driving spam/bot traffic versus which projects were driving real users to the Optimism ecosystem. 

These metrics and the analysis was used in the RPGF4 voting and review process, improving the understanding and (we believe) the outcome for voters by informing which projects were driving real humans, and organic users to the collective versus which were just bringing short term bots or spam users to the network (often low value and transient).

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: Our infrastructure and tooling has benefited the Badgeholder community the most, through our support of the RPGF rounds. Although we have made humanity proofs available via Attestations for nearly a year now on Optimism, the real value of this work has come from the inclusion and integration with the badgeholder experience (and collaboration with OSO) when reviewing and voting for projects to receive rewards.

name: Grant Innovation Lab
description: The Grant Innovation Lab is a research group with Metagov focused on better understanding grant programs from inception through impact. We have produced reports such as the State of Web3 Grants 2023, 3 Retroactive Funding Case Studies, the Grant Maturity Index, and the State of Web3 Grants 2024. We also host quarterly calls for grant operators and have hosted multiple in-person events for grant operators.

impactStatement.answer: Those who are interested in better understanding grant programs relative to other programs. Those who want to partake in conversations pertaining to outputs, outcomes, and impact. Those who generally want to partake in discussions around how to improve capital allocation.

name: Quantitative Simulations and Analysis of RetroPGF Voting Mechanisms
description:
Badgeholder behavior is a crucial determinant of the amount of funding a project will receive in RetroPGF. In this project, we develop various models of badgeholder behavior that include real-world effects such as varying levels of expertise and laziness, and implement them in an agent-based simulator to simulate various aspects of RetroPGF voting mechanisms. The purpose of these simulations is to test aspects of voting mechanisms quantitatively. Specifically, we are interested in testing how various voting mechanisms (such as Quorum + Threshold, or Pairwise) compare along the following dimensions:  1) capital allocation efficiency, 2) robustness to COI (conflict of interest), and 3) robustness to collusion. 

Our summary findings, which are detailed in the project resources, are:
When controlling for badgeholder laziness and expertise, the pairwise voting mechanism results in a closer alignment between true project rankings and the rankings inferred by the voting mechanism.
Quorum+Threshold, across a wide range of parameters, appears more resilient to COI and collusion than Pairwise.

github.name: Voting Mechanism Design
github.description: This repository contains agent based simulations of badgeholders interacting with different voting mechanisms, such as pairwise and quorum+threshold.  Additionally, it contains Jupyter notebooks that utilize the agent based simulations to determine the COI and collusion performance of the different voting mechanisms.

grants.details: This grant commissioned three different teams to investigate different aspects of the robustness of voting mechanism designs. Our team focused on using a simulation based approach to assess the robustness of different voting mechanisms to COI and collusion.

links.name: A Quantitative Simulation of Pairwise Voting for RetroPGF
links.description:
This blog post details how we used the voting_mechanism_design software to assess the performance of the pairwise voting mechanism.  The effectiveness of the mechanism and discovering the true project rankings, conflict of interest (COI) and collusion performance are all discussed for the pairwise voting mechanism. 

We find pairwise voting may be more efficient at allocating capital to impactful projects than the Quorum+Threshold mechanism, irrespective of badgeholder laziness and expertise.  

Impact:
- X statistics:  
    - 5000 views - https://x.com/Filecoin/status/1830573340513165484 
    - 380 views - https://x.com/cryptoeconlab/status/1826290227717046411 
- Posted on Medium, received 65 views and 33 reads.
- Presented at regenlearnings.xyz meeting in September, video recording here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BYrJb5KmRiI

links.name: The robustness of Quorum+Threshold Voting Mechanism to Conflicts of Interest in RetroPGF
links.description:
In this article, we assess the robustness of the Quorum+Threshold voting mechanism to COI voting behavior, and compare it to Pairwise voting.  We outline an approach to quantitatively measuring this, and explain experiments and results.  

We find that Q+T voting exhibits more robustness to COI than Pairwise, in our models of badgeholder behavior for each voting mechanism.  However, this and the previous analysis indicate that there are several dimensions to assess a voting mechanism.  Capital allocation efficiency, robustness to negative behaviors, and other factors all play a role. 

Impact:
- Posted on Medium, received 15 views and 6 reads as of Sat Oct 12.
- 146 Views on Twitter.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer: Our work specifically focused on assessing the robustness of voting mechanisms, which are a central aspect of Optimism's PGF efforts. The robustness of these mechanisms to conflict of interest and collusion were not quantitatively assessed previously, and therefore, it was not previously known how well the voting mechanism that we used would far in light of negative behaviors.  Our work sheds light on this, and elucidates the tradeoffs that need to be taken into account when deciding which voting mechanism to use when designing an RPG round.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: The optimism ecosystem, and specifically, the round organizers and designers of PGF funding efforts  will benefit from this infrastructure and tooling. The recommendations provided in the articles surrounding the quantitative simulations as well as the developed simulation codebase can enable round organizers to choose both the correct voting mechanism as well as the appropriate parameters to achieve the desired tradeoff between voting mechanism efficiency and robustness to negative behaviors.

name: Optimism Grant analytics: Grant3
description:
Grant3 is the most Comprehensive Grants database for Optimism. With Over 1078 Projects and 134 Million OP distributed through Optimism are manually tracked on Grant3.

Problem:
Currently data about Grantees of OP Collective is scattered across multiple different platforms like OP Governance Forum, Charmverse and RetroPGF Platform. There is no single platform where members of the OP collective can easily view and track Grantees with their grant details.

With Grant3, viewers can easily view details of all the grantees in a single place making it easy for tracking, collaboration and verification, fostering deeper collaboration within the OP Community.

Features of Grant3 incude
- Grantee Database: A database with more than 134M OP Tracked and 1000+ grantee projects tracked.
- Grants Timeline: a unified timeline informing potential applicants about past and upcoming grant programs on Optimism
- Dashboard : Single point of information on all things grants for Optimism
- Articles: In-depth information about Optimism and its grant programs
- OP Analytics: Data sources to dig deeper into the OP ecosystem

links.name: OP Grants Bulletin Board
links.description: A single source of information for all current, upcoming Grants programs and announcements in Optimism. All the ongoing grants are listed in a timeline format for users to find out the current opportunities they can apply to within Optimism.

links.name: OP Grant Articles
links.description: Detailed information on various events happening within the OP grants domain. The articles give users a complete understanding of the Grants processes and helps them with granular details.

links.name: OP Analytics
links.description: A generalized data aggregation on various statistics for the OP Ecosystem.

links.name: OP Grantee Database
links.description:
The most Comprehensive database on OP grants with 1078 Projects tracked and 134 Million OP Tokens distributed. Our Grantee database aggregates data on OP Grants from multiple platforms like OP Forums, Charmverse and RetroPGF. 

The intuitive layout and functionality of the Database makes it easy to filter grantees based on various parameters like Cycles (Cycle 27, Cycle 26, Cycle 19 and more), Grant Types (RetroPGF, Growth experiments, Builders, Intents, Audits), Grant Amount (Under 50K, over 50K) and tags (Superchain, data, infrastructure, NFT) and more. The search functionality provides additional feature to directly search for Grantee projects

links.name: OP Grants Dashboard
links.description: A single point of information for all statistics about OP Grants. Users can find the number of Projects granted, the amount of OP granted. Furthermore users can find more information about each Cycle of the Grants council, its number of winners and total OP distributed for the particular cycle

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
Grant Allocation, Grant Program Analytics and Grantee Tracker:

The OP grant tracker is the largest data source for Optimism Grants, which in turn is one of the largest data source for Grantee details in the Web3. Till date the project has tracked more than 1078 grantees with a total allocation of more than 134 Million OP. The tracker adds grant awardees on a continuous  basis with data on the latest Cycle grantees also available for users to view and analyze.

Currently, the data on OP Grantees is highly fragmented, scattered over multiple platforms like Charmverse, OP Forums and RetroPGF Interface. There is no unified interface for users to view data on all grantees that have received OP from the Treasury.

Beyond the numbers, the tracker presents the data on grantees in a simple and intuitive interface, enabling users to easily narrow down their research based on various parameters like Grants cycles, grant type, grant size and tags.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Delegates in decision making: Delegates do not have the bandwidth to do in-depth research and make informed decisions on Grants when the data is so scattered. The OP Grants tracker makes it easy to compare performances of various Grant cycles with qualitative and quantitative measures.

2. Grants Council Members in Grantee tracking: For each cycle, get a list of grantees, their application links and granular details related to their application. Our research enables GC Members to track projects that have ceased operations despite winning grants or have not performed up to the expectations, facilitating learning for future grant screening.

3. Potential Grant Applicants in grants research: Potential applicants search grantees with similar area of focus (defi, data, infra, etc) and analyze successful applications. Furthermore, applicants get a better picture of the rubrics and reporting requirements, giving them more chances of success.

4. OP Collective Members in general analytics

name: Mission Tracking Dashboard Season5
description:
As an active contributor to the Optimism DAO, I have proactively led multiple grants analyses and taken initiative to build tools that bring real value to both delegates and grant applicants. The Mission Tracking Dashboard for Season 5 was designed with a clear purposeâ€”to bring structure and visibility to a chaotic process and make mission tracking simpler, more transparent, and efficient for everyone involved.

Key features and values of the dashboard include:

Centralized Access: All essential resourcesâ€”application templates, guides, social channels, and workshop recordingsâ€”were brought together in one platform, making it easy to navigate.

Live, Intent-Wise Tracking: The dashboard offered real-time updates on mission requests by intent, providing crucial details such as requested budgets, proposer information, number of applicants, and current status. This allowed applicants to easily decide which mission requests to apply for.

Voting Insights: During the voting phase, the dashboard proved invaluable by providing clear visibility into all passed mission requests, ensuring transparency and enabling informed decision-making for both delegates and voters.

Enhanced Engagement: By providing real-time updates and key resources in one place, the dashboard increased engagement from both delegates and grant applicants, allowing them to follow the process seamlessly.

Scalability: As the number of mission requests and proposals increased, the dashboard helped manage the growing complexity, offering a structured and organized solution that controlled everything.

By proactively creating this tool, I brought clarity, structure, and engagement to what can often be a complex and chaotic process. The Mission Tracking Dashboard became essential to ensuring smooth operations, benefiting both delegates and grant applicants during Season 5.

links.name: Mission Tracker Dashboard
links.description:
This dashboard was created by analysing the new change at the start of Season 5 with Mission Requests and Intents. This dashboard allowed many delegates & applicants to easily navigate, learn, vote & apply to different Missions. The exact number of visitors are difficult to identify as the spreadsheet doesn't allow that. I would like to add a link to the comment(https://gov.optimism.io/t/missions-v2-season-5/6897/10?u=chain_l) in the forum which allows you to see the number of clicks by unique accounts to the dashboard. 
Apart from this, it was also posted on Discord where it was well received. https://discord.com/channels/667044843901681675/1192613359267352676

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
My work focused on improving mission request tracking, enhancing process clarity, and boosting efficiency. The dashboard allowed delegates to easily learn how to apply, how much to ask for, and monitor progress, ensuring informed decision-making. For grant applicants, it simplified aligning applications with mission requests, so they knew exactly which request to apply for, reducing confusion.

The tool also proved invaluable for voters during the voting process. It provided a clear, intent-wise snapshot of all mission requests, allowing them to see the big picture of budget allocation and compare the asks of different requests. This eliminated the need to manually navigate through each forum link, saving time and reducing overwhelm. Voters could quickly assess and compare the status and requests, ensuring more efficient and informed decision-making without getting lost in the complexity of multiple mission requests scattered across the forum.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
70+ visitors (delegates, applicants, voters) leveraged the dashboard for tracking, aligning proposals, and efficiently comparing mission requests for allocating budget intent-wise.
The dashboardâ€™s clarity and structure increased engagement across all stakeholders, from mission requests to voting outcomes.
A simplified and transparent mission tracking system made the governance process easier for new participants.
Improved proposal alignment enhanced the quality and effectiveness of applications, making the process more efficient and impactful for all involved.

name: OP Governance App
description:
Agora built and maintains the voting application of the Optimism Token House. Over 70 proposals have been conducted through this interface we've developed with an average of 8.7k voters on each vote.

Agora developed unique capabilities for the Optimism Governor such as: 
1. Approval voting for multiple choice voting, typically used funding collective intents
2. Optimistic voting, typically used for code of conduct enforcement.
3. Multiple proposal types with unique quorums and approval thresholds that conform to the Collective's operating manual.

We've also been continuously making UX improvements on the application such as:
1. Displaying charts for vote progress
2. Improving the UI to reduce the potential of error in casting approval votes
3. Improving the proposal creation flow for the OP Foundation

Note â€“ all of Agora's projects are being worked on by our full team of 12 (viewable here https://www.agora.xyz/#About) Contributors listed on our projects are only the admins involved in completing our profile and do not represent the full headcount involved in projects.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The OP governance app (vote.optimism.io) is how users interact with the contracts powering the core logic of Token House voting. From Oct 1, 2023 - September 18th 2024, around 50 proposals were created and voted on by an average of 8.7k voters each. 

These proposals have ranged from critical protocol upgrades for OP like Fault Proofs to mission requests allocating millions of OP to fund the Collective's intents.

During this period, we've also introduced several major innovations to the voting app that's made the OP token house UX better, such as:

1. Improving the approval voting experience to reduce the error rate
2. Improving the proposal creation flow to make the process easier to manage

Token House voters: delegates vote on proposals on the app

OP foundation: the foundation manage creates proposals on the app

Mission request recipients: all intents and mission requests are funded using an approval vote.

Grant council, Security Council, Developer advisory board: all committees on Optimism are appointed through the use of an approval vote.

name: Aragon
description: Aragon was founded in 2016 with the belief that the fate of humanity will be decided at the frontier of technological innovation and human collaboration. Aragon launched the first DAO Framework in 2017 which secures over $40 billion in TVL. Aragonâ€™s tech stack allows anyone to launch a DAO, enabling organizations to securely govern their protocols and assets onchain.

github.name: Aragon App Github
github.description: The Aragon App is a human-centered no-code interface that allows anyone to deploy and manage a DAO onchain. Anyone can deploy a delegate voting DAO or â€œmultisigâ€ DAO on five chains, in under 10 minutes. They can also mint ERC20Votes governance tokens. Participants can transparently find all of the information they need to participate, including membership, proposals, transactions, and settings. They can easily create and vote on complex onchain proposals with tools like the Smart Contract Composer and dApp Connect (allowing DAOs to interact with dApps like an EOA).

github.name: Aragon OSx Github
github.description: Aragon OSx is a DAO framework that allows developers to build, deploy, and evolve custom DAOs onchain. Governance logic is programmed into plugins, making custom and granular governance designs easier, faster, and safer to build. It allows organizations to build multi-body, multi-process, and multichain governance, tailored to their unique needs. Plugins can be installed, upgraded, and uninstalled, allowing DAOs to evolve over time, onchain, via their governance process. All DAOs built on Aragon OSx can benefit from the modularity of the framework, by easily installing open source plugins built by others.

grants.details: We've received a grant to build, together with RISC Zero, a cutting edge crosschain voting solution that will also be compatible with the OP stack. We've agreed to split the original grant amount with another project that applied, so a retro allocation could fill our building gap

links.name: Aragon OSx - data overview
links.description:
Aragon OSx DAO framework is fully onchain, therefore we've build this dashboard to track the current DAOs that are deployed.
It does not yet showcase the latest Custom builds of Puffer & Mode that have bring our TVG over $2B

Aragon also launched it's DAO framework on Base and we're closely working with with Mode to launch their DAO too. This shows that we are deeply committed to building on the Superchain

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
In the past year, we deployed our stack on Base, resulting in the creation of nearly 2,000 DAOs on that chain. More recently, weâ€™ve collaborated with Mode to develop their DAO with novel tokenomics aspects built into their governance model.

Besides that we've been working closely with relevant OP stakeholders like the Foundation and the grants council to develop a cutting edge cross-chain voting module that is desigend to be highly modular and adaptable. This allows other projects on Optimism to easily integrate with it or build on top of it. And thanks to Optimismâ€™s ground-breaking work adopting EIP-4844 blobs into the OP blocks, weâ€™ll be able to remove any trusted component and directly use Ethereumâ€™s merkelized roots.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Protocols and their token holders that are build on Base are currently the ones who are benefitting the most from our free-to-use and open source governance tooling.
With Mode's launch we've been rapidly expanding already and we would like to include more projects on the superchain in the near future. 

Our unique value proposition is that the governance logic is programmed into plugins, making custom and granular governance designs easier, faster, and safer to build. It allows organizations to build multi-body, multi-process, and multichain governance, tailored to their unique needs. Plugins can be installed, upgraded, and uninstalled, allowing DAOs to evolve over time, onchain, via their governance process. As we expand to Optimism's Superchain, projects will instantly benefit from open-source plugins that have been battle-tested (with actual Lindy build on the plug-ins) and adopted by others.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?

The following Optimism Collective stakeholder group benefits most from our work:

OP Delegates, Citizen and Contributors: Individuals involved in Optimism Collective operations leveraged our platform and resources to get a comprehensive overview of key Governance elements.

OP Token holders and aspiring contributors: Our analytics work and platform allowed a wider audience to remain up to date with all Optimism Collective governance and Superchain developments. Our newsletter, insights and platform have provided context to over ~25K individuals.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
CharmVerse powered the end to end grants process of the Grants Council, servicing a total of 1,171 applications across Season 5 and 6. The process includes application intake, Council evaluation, communication & notifications, and milestone tracking. 

Over the past 12 months, monthly active users ranged from ~1k to 4.4k. In Cycle 19, NPS from finalist was 9/10, exceeding target of 7/10, indicating high satisfaction levels among applicants with the grants process. 

"Special acknowledgment is due to the Charmverse team for their instrumental role in providing the necessary tools to facilitate the review process. Leveraging the rubric, workflow, and form tools for the first time, we achieved an impressive success rate of 97.2% out of 314 applications without errors and solved any issues on a 12-hour gap" - Gonna, Grants Council Lead

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
We work closely with the Grants Council and constantly evolve the platform to meet their specific needs and ensure great grantee experience in a timely manner. Both the Grants Council and grant applicants benefit from a transparent and efficient grants process. 

"We are delighted to announce that rubric comments are now integrated directly into your applications. Simply navigate to your application and check the sidebar to find scores for each rubric section, along with comments from reviewers. A huge thanks to the Charmverse team for implementing this feature so quickly." - Gonna, Grants Council Lead

name: Optimism Governance Calls
description:
The Joint House and Token House calls are the main place where delegates and badgeholders discuss ongoing issues in Optimism Governance. These calls happen every two weeks and have brought a wide variety of guests for the benefit of the Collective. We have had many upgrade AMAs with engineers from OP Labs and Base, discussions around decentralization, grant recipients presenting grant results, and members from the Optimism Foundation giving presentations on Optimism Governance.

This project also includes other hosted events such as Badgeholder & Delegate Speed Dating, AMAs, Mission Request Brainstorm Sessions, etc.

This work is not supported by grants or salary and instead is 100% supported by Retro Funding.
