There have been 23 community governance calls in this impact period. In addition, we have had two "speed dating" sessions, mission request workshops, and other AMAs.

The calls have been a key place to discuss *everything* that has happened in governance during that time, and calls usually get 40-50 key participants from Optimism Governance.

A small sampling of topics/guests in this impact period:
* Jing presenting and Q&A on the Superchain vision
* Base Governance team Rowan & Saemi discussing Base's participation
* Ben Jones presenting Blockspace Charters
* Kelvin Fitchner Granite Network Upgrade AMA
* Justine with a Season 6 Governance AMA
* Launamu preseting Impact Metrics Garden
* PaperImperium discussing a proposal on accelerated governance decentralization
* Roberto Bayardo (Base) presenting Fjord/Ecotone upgrades
* Emily presenting Guest Voter Participation
* Jonas presenting multiple Retro Funding rounds

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?

These calls are the critical space for all governance participants to become informed, ask questions, and discuss every current issue across the Token House and the Citizen's House.

By condensing all of this information into 1 hour and by bringing experts into the discussion, Delegates and Citizens are able to participate more effectively across every area of Optimism Governance.

name: Optimism Developer Advisory Board (S6)
description:
The Developer Advisory Board (DAB) brings a technical perspective to everything that happens in Optimism governance. 

Running the Collective requires a lot of important technical decision making:
- Which upgrades are safe? 
- Which projects are making a meaningful technical impact? 
- Which grants deserve to be funded?

The DAB works to ensure these decisions are made correctly. Our responsibilities include supporting Grants Council with technical assessments of projects, supporting citizens and delegates with simple protocol upgrade explanations, and being a nexus for communication between OP Labs, the Foundation, delegates, citizens, developers, and other stakeholders.

grants.details: DAB S6's initial budget. From the [initial charter](https://gov.optimism.io/t/developer-advisory-board/6892#advisory-board-budget-9): "The initial budget will be important to attract top talent, but ... recommend the board be primarily rewarded retroactively."

subcategory: Councils, Commissions and Advisory Boards; NERD programs focused exclusively on core governance responsibilities (GovNERDs)::This includes Security Council, Grants Council, Developer Advisory Board, Code of Conduct Council, Anticapture Commission, Collective Feedback Commissions and GovNERDs.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 6: May 9th - September 18th 2024 (up until Voting Cycle #28)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Developer Advisory Board (DAB) was reelected in Season 6. [Our charter can be found in the initial budget proposal](https://gov.optimism.io/t/zach-obront-developer-advisory-board-operating-budget/8141), and includes supporting the Optimism ecosystem as follows:

1. Help to ensure the safety of protocol upgrades. We do this by both (a) explicitly approving upgrades before they are allowed to move to a vote and (b) providing plain English summaries of all protocol upgrades to educate other voters.

2. Support the Grants Council by providing detailed technical feedback on all Mission Requests, Mission Applications, and grant milestones.

3. Bring an additional technical perspective to thinking about the vision of the OP ecosystem and what needs to happen to get there.

More details can be found in our [Internal Operating Procedures](https://gov.optimism.io/t/developer-advisory-board-s6-internal-operating-procedures/8558).

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
- Provided detailed feedback on [139 mission requests](https://wbnns.notion.site/Developer-Advisory-Board-Impact-11acf4706b47808f8421c409b4c102c6?pvs=4) thus far (105 of which are within the round eligibility period), to aid in evaluation by the Grants Council. The GC Lead has provided an NPS score of 10/10 based on the value of our contributions.
- Reviewed the Granite Hardfork, formally approved it, and prepared an [extensive and comprehensive non-technical summary](https://gov.optimism.io/t/upgrade-proposal-10-granite-network-upgrade/8733/21) to support other voters.
- Provided feedback to the Foundation on important projects such as the Decentralization Roadmap and long term Product Vision.
- Conducted multiple community calls throughout Season 6, [creating an open forum](https://gov.optimism.io/t/developer-advisory-board-feedback-ideas-thread/8580) to get feedback and ideas from the community.

Optimism Delegates â€“ Delegates can leverage our tooling to automate and streamline governance processes

With this infrastructure, Ethereans Protocol promotes decentralized decision-making, accountability, and community participation across all layers of governance in Optimism.

name: Eden Fractal Events
description:
Eden Fractal is a community dedicated to optimizing collective decision-making through fractal consensus processes and prosocial games. We've hosted over a hundred events over the past three years, fostering collaboration among governance leaders, builders, and community members across various ecosystems. These events are focused on implementing fractal governance processes throughout society via collaborative research, development, education, gamification, and community engagement.

Eden Fractal serves as a research and development hub for governance innovations, particularly focusing on fractal democracy and gamified governance processes. We provide a platform for governance leaders to network, share ideas, and experiment with new decision-making models that can enhance Optimism's governance structures. Our community has been instrumental in developing and refining tools and processes that are now being used in Optimism Fractal and other communities on the Superchain. By hosting Eden Fractal events, we've created a consistent space for governance experimentation and education, contributing to the evolution of Optimism's governance landscape.

This work has not been funded by the Collective outside of the RetroPGF Round 3 grant shown below, which supported the team who started Eden Fractal as well as our work with several other related projects. You can see Optimystics.io/projects-and-funding for details on our organizationâ€™s funding and applications for related projects.

links.description: A page that features various metrics and measures demonstrating the impact of Eden Fractal events

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
Fractal Democracy: We've pioneered implementation of fractal governance structures, providing a scalable model for decentralized decision-making that could enhance all Optimism governance.

Prosocial Game Experimentation: Weâ€™ve designed and tested various iterations of onchain social games and consensus processes, fostering collaborative product and strategy development for collective decision-making processes on Optimism.

Governance Tool Development: We've facilitated discussions and demonstrations of various governance tools, supporting their development and integration into communities interested in them across the Optimism ecosystem and beyond.

Governance Knowledge Hub: We host and record discussions with diverse blockchain governance leaders, building a rich educational resource for governance innovation and strategy.

Our consistent events have provided a stable environment for ongoing governance experimentation, contributing to the evolution of Optimism's governance landscape

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Governance Innovation Incubation: By providing a regular forum for experimentation with 37 events since last October, we've accelerated the development and refinement of governance tools now used in Optimism Fractal and several other communities.

2. Governance Education: Our events and videos have provided an accessible entry point for both newcomers and leaders across the Superchain to learn about and engage with advanced Optimism governance concepts.

3. Prototype Testing: Our community has served as an initial testing ground for governance innovations before their wider implementation in Optimism Fractal or the broader Collective.

4. Governance Laboratory: Our long-running event series serves as a platform for iterative improvements, constantly refining democratic processes and contributing to the evolution of the Optimism's governance mechanisms..

These improvements have strengthened Optimism's governance by fostering innovation, education, and cross-ecosystem collaboration.

name: Proving Retroactive Funding with EZKL
description: EZKL is the developer-friendly system for verifiable AI and analytics. We created a zero-knowledge proof of the fairness and correctness of the Retroactive Public Goods Funding results, starting with round 3. Anyone can verify it at https://retrofunding.ezkl.xyz and you can read more at https://blog.ezkl.xyz/post/zkrpgf/

We leverage ezkl to build the circuit directly from the python code in a jupyter notebook rpgf3_allocator.ipynb. The notebook has associated markdown cells that explain the circuit and the steps to build it.

subcategory: Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history
Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Badgeholder votes are private. This allows voters to express their true preferences without fear of retaliation, coercion, or pressure from others. It makes it difficult to execute vote buying, and encourages honest participation. It doesn't protect against the vote counter cheating.

Even though the allocation algorithm is public (and we can check that it accurately codifies forum promises), we canâ€™t run a check without the input data. In the worst case, we canâ€™t guarantee that the provided allocation algorithm was even used or that all votes were counted.

We made this process transparent with zero-knowledge (ZK) proof that legitimate votes were counted and that the allocation algorithm was run as intended, keeping the votes themselves private. Using EZKL, we were able to compile the Python allocation code into a circuit, and provide a proof anyone can verify at https://retrofunding.ezkl.xyz (see https://blog.ezkl.xyz/post/zkrpgf/ for more details).

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The Retroactive Public Goods Funding process ideally improves with each round via governance feedback. We cryptographically audited Round 3 in a replicable way, providing a cryptographic proof any stakeholder can verify in a browser. This paves the way for an end-to-end automated process with private voting, checks and balances on the allocation algorithm, and smart contract enabled allocation delivery

For stakeholders, this cryptographic audit means many things:
- For badgeholders, your vote was fairly counted
- For recipients, your allocation was fairly calculated
- For everyone else, the results actually correspond with Optimism governance â€” governance at work!

Blockchains have both social consensus (which fork is the main one, which client should be run, etc.) and computational consensus. By verifying the RetroPGF results, everyone helps solidify the social consensus around the legitimacy of the vote. You are an election observer, contributing to a successful audit.

name: OP Badgeholder Analysis and Dashboard
description: This project works to provide a comprehensive understanding of OP Badgeholder's On Chain activity and how it compares to the activity of active Optimism/Ethereum users. In a publicly accessible Dune dashboard, we analyze Badgeholder characteristics including their relative rates of activity on and off the Superchain, participation in governance, use of NFTs and smart contract deployments, and presence on social apps like Farcaster. This analysis provides OP governance with the information they need to continue equitably and effectively expanding the citizenry.

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance
Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We have created a comprehensive analysis of Optimism Badgeholder's onchain activity vs a control group of active non-Badgeholders. In particular, we looked at transaction activity across chains, involvement in social apps (Farcaster, Lens, Friendtech), participation in other DAOs (Arbitrum, Uniswap, ENS) and the deployment of smart contracts and NFTs. 

Something to note: although it is true that not all citizens use their Badgeholder address for other onchain activity, we found that a significant amount did and we discuss the implications of this constraint in the report.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
The Optimism Foundation. This work was requested directly by the Foundation in order to get a better understanding of Optimism Badgeholders vs â€œnormalâ€ Ethereum users. In their own words: â€œIn order to confidently expand the Citizenry, we need to have a baseline understanding of the current Badgeholder group. Our goal is to get a better understanding of the Badgeholder group based on their onchain activity compared with the onchain activity of other active Optimism/Ethereum users.â€

In addition, the entire Optimism Collective has benefitted from the transparency provided by this publicly available work. It's open source nature sets the stage for others to conduct further research and expand upon our results.

name: Optimism Town Hall + RetroPitches
description:
Optimism Town Hall is a collaborative forum dedicated to discussions about Optimism governance, featuring innovative community agenda games. Between its launch in May 2023 and September, we hosted 19 weekly events where anyone can join to learn about the Superchain, help lead the Collective, and explore opportunities within the Optimism ecosystem. These events, leverage non-transferrable reputation tokens for democratic topic selection. Our experiments in community-driven agendas reveal that gamification is key to involving a broader spectrum of stakeholders in governance. This innovative approach, scalable across the Optimism Collective, reflects our commitment to creating engaging governance processes that inspire builders and users alike to participate in building an equitable internet.

RetroPitches, initiated in November 2023, are friendly competitions where public goods creators present their projects, and participants rank pitches. We've organized several pilot events, providing a platform for projects to showcase their work and for badgeholders to evaluate contributions effectively. These two initiatives serve as an interactive hub for governance discussions, connecting delegates, builders, and community members. We produce high-quality videos with detailed show notes, creating valuable educational resources about Optimism governance. By facilitating open dialogues and showcasing innovative projects, we're fostering a more engaged and informed Optimism community, directly supporting the Collective's governance processes and public goods funding initiatives.

This work has not received any funding from the Collective. This project is specifically for the facilitation of Optimism Town Hall and RetroPitches events, not the Optimism Fractal Respect Game events which take place before the town hall events. You can see Optimystics.io/projects-and-funding for details on our organizationâ€™s funding and applications for related projects.

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
Our work has supported these key governance processes and experiments:

1. Community-Driven Agenda Setting: We pioneered Cagendas and OPTOPICS, two collaborative topic selection processes using onchain reputation tokens, enhancing community engagement in governance discussions and contributing to the development of more effective deliberation methods.

2. Governance Education: Our events served as an interactive platform for newcomers and leaders across the Superchain to learn about and engage with Optimism's governance processes, including RetroFunding and missions.

3. RetroPGF Evaluation: RetroPitches events provided a platform for public goods creators to showcase their work, supporting the RetroPGF Round 3 evaluation process by offering badge holders insights into projects' impacts.

Governance Tool Showcases: We provided a regular forum for developers to present governance-related tools and innovations, supporting the evolution of Optimism's governance infrastructure.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
Our work has improved the performance of governance processes in several ways:

1. Enhanced Participation: By providing an accessible entry point to governance discussions and pioneering novel agenda games, we've increased engagement in Optimism governance and developed scalable processes that can be used to facilitate other key governance meetings.

2. Improved Information Flow: Our events and video content have created a more informed governance community, facilitating better decision-making and community knowledge in various governance processes.

3. Cross-Community Collaboration: We facilitated discussions between various stakeholders in the Optimism ecosystem, including delegates, council members, and builders, fostering a more cohesive governance community.

4. Governance Innovation Catalyst: By providing a platform for governance experiments and tool showcases, we've accelerated the development and adoption of innovative governance mechanisms within the Optimism ecosystem.

name: Retro 5 Expert Voter Selection: Developer Reputation Score using Recursive Trust
description:
[WHAT WE DID]

Guest voter selection for Retro 5, was based on software development expertise evident by a developer's Github user reputation score, under the guidance of Optimism Citizens House. The developer reputation scores are based on calculating recursive trust across the Github developer activity graph. This ranking is seeded by OP Stack repos. This means Github repos and developers 

This was an important experiment because certain retro funding rounds, such as this round, has particular expertise involved in assessing and judging the quality and impact of the applicant projects. In the case of Retro 5, the applicants are repos to OP Stack, therefore it makes sense to select top contributing and highly reputable developers as guest voters, so that the collective governance can benefit from their technical and topical expertise. are scored based on recursive trust signals, originating from these seed trust repos. https://gov.optimism.io/t/retro-funding-5-expert-voting-experiment/8613

More on our effort into applying the algorithm in custom context, pre and post processing the data, and iterations: https://gov.optimism.io/t/retro-funding-5-guest-voter-selection-algorithm-explanation/8719

[OUR IMPACT] 

30 top contributors to OP stack were identified and selected as expert voters for Retro 5 round - OP Stack.

74K+ Github developers were given a reputation score seeded to indicate their contribution, taken into consideration the quality of their code contribution, to Optimism core repo stacks. And the score results are readily available for any Optimism ecosystem projects to use.

[WHAT IS OpenRank]

OpenRank is a decentralized ranking and reputation protocol. It enables a verifiable reputation compute layer for the open web that unlocks a broad range of useful applications, including those that resist cryptographic or game-theoretic mechanisms of trust. Using graph compute algorithms like EigenTrust, it offers resilience from sybil contexts, provides scalable and context-specific compute, and enables permissionless access to compute and reputation data for any user.

We would say that the most important beneficiary is the Optimism governance collective itself.

name: OSO Insights & Data Science
description:
Open Source Observer is a public good that helps communities measure impact and improve grant effectiveness. Alongside our work providing impact metrics for specific funding rounds, we also employ data science to evaluate the long-term efficacy of Retro Funding as a mechanism and conduct robust analyses to ensure the integrity of each funding round.

We help the Optimism Collective analyze voter behavior and reward distribution patterns, project/contribution reputation, and the performance of cohorts of projects over time. These efforts are intended to provide the community with a more nuanced understanding of each round's effectiveness and inform future round designs.

In addition, we conduct ad hoc analyses to verify results calculations, screen projects for eligibility requirements, and create synthetic data for testing purposes. This work is high-context and requires a deep understanding of each round's design parameters, voters, and project pools.

Our insights leverage both our OSO data pipeline and a variety of partner data sources, including Farcaster, OpenRank, Agora, Ethereum Attestation Service, and others. All of our work is public and intended to be easily reproducible by the community.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
Our work is primarily focused on analyzing grant allocations and the participation / revealed preferences of badgeholders during Retro Funding voting.

For instance, after each round during the current period (ie, RF3 and RF4), we authored an "Opening up the ballot box" piece, looking in detail at various voter patterns, biases, and clustering effects. 

Another example is our "longitudinal analysis" piece, which looks at distinct cohorts of Retro Funding projects over time and identifies patterns related to grant allocation and project growth / momentum. 

In addition to these retrospective pieces, we also assist Optimism Governance (and partners) to simulate voter behaviors and biases when designing rounds and voting interfaces.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
The reality is that most of our insights are targeted at governance nerds: the most active/engaged  badgeholders, the Foundation, and a subset of Token House members who are active on the governance forum.

Our ideas have been quoted in round design specs (see [here](https://gov.optimism.io/t/upcoming-retro-rounds-and-their-design/7861)) as well as in good-natured debate about the efficacy of grant allocation results (see [here](https://gov.optimism.io/t/new-rpgf3-distribution-disparity-data/7521)). 

Our post on the [300+ OSS projects applying for RF3](https://gov.optimism.io/t/analysis-on-the-300-oss-projects-applying-for-retropgf-3/7127) received 90+ likes on the governance forum, putting it in [the top 5](https://gov.optimism.io/top?period=yearly) of all posts over the period.

name: Onchain Impact Metrics for Retro Funding
description:
Open Source Observer is a public good that helps communities measure impact and improve grant effectiveness. During Retro Funding 4 (Onchain Builders), we collaborated closely with the Citizens House to develop a comprehensive suite of onchain impact metrics and power the first "metrics-based voting" experiment.

We created a first-of-its-kind data pipeline for the Superchain: not only the data but also all source code, query logic, and underlying infrastructure is publicly available for use. With data generously provided by Goldsky, we built a unified Superchain event model covering all OP Stack chains (OP Mainnet, Base, Fraxtal, Metal, Mode, and Zora). We wrote custom logic for discovering contract deployments and attributing them to specific projects per RF4 requirements. With our friends at OpenRank, Passport, and the OP Labs data team, we designed a "trusted user model", intended to identify transaction and onchain activity from high reputation users. These models provided the foundation for calculating a range of quantitative indicators to assess the contributions of onchain builders across these chains. All methodologies, data sources, and analysis tools used in developing these metrics are publicly available.

We also maintain an important community resource called OSS Directory: a public repository of Optimism projects and their associated GitHub repos, NPM packages, deployers, contracts, and other open source artifacts, with a strict schema and validation logic to ensure consistency. There are more than 500 Optimism projects in the directory, with new submissions and updates coming in every week. During the RF4 sign-up period, we received 50+ new submissions and made numerous updates to existing projects. 

The journey to arrive at a final set of onchain impact metrics was iterative and collaborative. We worked closely with the Foundation and badgeholders to discover and refine the metrics through workshops, surveys, and asynchronous feedabck. This collaboration not only provided valuable insights for Retro Funding 4 but also laid the groundwork for more sophisticated impact assessment in subsequent rounds.

In all the work leading up to the final voting, we maintained our commitment to openness and reproducibility, and wrote extensively about the process to arrive at the final set of metrics on our blog and the Optimism governance forum.

github.name: OSS Directory
github.description: A curated directory of open source software (OSS) projects and their associated artifacts. We use this directory to map projects to onchain artifacts such as deployers, factories, or specific deployments of various chains. We also capture GitHub organizations/repos, packages, social media accounts, etc.

github.description: This is the monorepo where the magic happens. It contains all of our infra (source definitions, indexing pipelines, orchestration, etc) and data models for creating impact metrics, as well as our docs and blog.

links.name: A deeper dive on the impact metrics for Optimism Retro Funding 4
links.description: This blog post provides a complete description of the work we did to power impact metrics for Retro Funding 4. It includes links to all our data sources, code, and metric models. It also discusses the journey we took with the Citizens House to design, iterate, and apply the impact metrics.

links.name: Retro Funding 4: Impact Metrics, a Collective Experiment
links.description: This forum post captures many of the public conversations about the evolution of impact metrics with the Citizens House during Retro Funding 4.

links.name: Lineage graph of RF4 impact metrics
links.description: This is our dbt-generated lineage graph (best viewed on a desktop screen), which provides an audit trail of every impact metric used in RF4. At the beginning of the graph, you see our primary data sources: raw transaction/trace data from 6 OP Stack chains; third-party data from Farcaster, OpenRank, and Passport; and project-contract relationships defined in OSS Directory and the Agora sign-up interface. At the end of the graph, you a single table of metrics by project that was served to the voting interface. In the middle, you see all of the processing and transformation necessary to connect the two!

subcategory: Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
OSO's infrastructure was critical to Retro Funding 4, which used "metrics-based voting" instead of the more traditional "project-based voting" interface.

Metrics-based voting had never been tried before -- let alone for hundreds of projects across various chains. The data infrastructure we built was able to respond to all of this complexity and power a successful voting experience. (The same infrastructure was also used to screen projects for eligibility and assist with open source licensing checks.)

Once the models were released, we posted an audit/bug bounty to the community. Fortunately, no issues were raised. Months later, there still have not been any. ðŸ˜…

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
We believe our infrastructure has been most valuable for Citizens, the Foundation, and other long-term minded governance participants.

As the Superchain scales, it will become increasingly impossible for every participant to have a detailed understanding of every project or category of projects. Data is necessary not only to better leverage the time of experts and ordinary citizens but also to create a more even playing field for builders.

Badgeholders had many positive things to say about the experience, from significant time savings to trusting that the distribution would be fairer / more meritocratic.

name: Token Engineering Commons
description: The Token Engineering Commons (TEC) is a decentralized autonomous organization (DAO) on the OP chain, committed to fostering the development of trustworthy and sustainable token economies. Its mission is to help establish a new engineering discipline that blends the principles, tools, and practices of traditional engineering with the design of cryptoeconomic systems. The TEC achieves this by promoting awareness and education around token engineering, while also offering grants and other opportunities to support projects that empower individuals and teams to innovate and advance the field.

github.name: Tunable Quadratic Funding
github.description: TQF is a research initiative by the Token Engineering Commons that enables transparent and informed quadratic funding round operation with a focus on utilizing token signal inputs to add tunable weights to donations based on donor token holdings.

links.name: Token Engineering the Superchain - Testing Hybrid Funding Experiments for the OP Ecosystem
links.description: The Token Engineering Commons (TEC) launched an innovative experiment in the second half of 2024, aiming to promote token engineering within the Optimism and Superchain ecosystems. This initiative combined Quadratic Funding (QF) with Retroactive Funding, introducing a novel capital allocation mechanism called Tunable Quadratic Funding (TQF). The experiment consisted of two rounds: a Gitcoin Grants 21 QF round in August, followed by a retroactive funding round in November using Gitcoin's EasyRetro on Allo Protocol. TEC will invest $50,000 across these rounds, with Gitcoin contributing an additional $50,000 match for the QF round. The project emphasizes Superchain impact, incorporating voting boosts for Superchain stakeholders and focusing on projects that catalyze token engineering adoption in the Superchain. Throughout the experiment, TEC organized educational events to explain token engineering and showcase grantees' work to key Superchain stakeholders, with the aim to build more trustworthy blockchain systems.

links.name: Results of Token Engineering the Superchain - TQF Report
links.description:
The Token Engineering the Superchain Grants Round: Summer/Fall 2024 delivered significant impact to the Optimism ecosystem through its innovative use of Tunable Quadratic Funding (TQF). By strategically boosting the voting weights of OP badgeholders and delegates, the round ensured that funding decisions were closely aligned with the expertise and priorities of key Optimism stakeholders. This approach resulted in the allocation of $60,000 across 18 carefully selected projects, each demonstrating strong potential to advance both token engineering principles and the Optimism Superchain ecosystem.

The TQF mechanism's focus on OP signals amplified the influence of community leaders, with OP Delegate Tokens Delegated receiving a 7x boost and OP Badgeholders an 8x boost. This targeted approach ensured that projects receiving funding were not only technically sound but also strongly aligned with Optimism's long-term vision and goals. As a result, the round saw a notable increase in projects directly addressing Superchain-specific challenges and opportunities, fostering innovation tailored to Optimism's unique ecosystem.

Moreover, the round's dual-phase structure, combining upfront quadratic funding with a planned retroactive funding phase, creates a powerful incentive for funded projects to deliver tangible results. This approach is poised to drive sustained, measurable impact within the Optimism ecosystem, encouraging projects to focus on real-world implementation and adoption of token engineering principles within the Superchain context. By leveraging the expertise of Optimism's most engaged community members through the TQF mechanism, this grants round has set a new standard for targeted, community-driven funding in the Web3 space, promising long-term benefits for both the token engineering field and the Optimism ecosystem at large.

links.name: Token Engineering the Superchain Grants Round Retro Report
links.description:
The Token Engineering the Superchain Grants Round for Summer/Fall 2024 demonstrated significant impact in advancing both token engineering and the Optimism ecosystem. With total distributions of $60k across 18 projects and total donations of $5,792.59 from 349 unique donors across 914 contributions, the round supported 18 carefully selected projects, each receiving an average grant of $3,333. This more focused approach, compared to previous rounds, led to stronger alignment with the dual objectives of advancing token engineering and driving Superchain impact. The round successfully implemented an innovative Tunable Quadratic Funding (TQF) mechanism, incorporating expertise signals to ensure aligned funding decisions.

Despite a decrease in overall participation compared to the previous round, the average contribution remained stable at $16.6, indicating sustained engagement from committed supporters. Notably, 11 out of 18 projects were returning grantees, suggesting continued progress and alignment with the ecosystem's goals. The round also set the foundation for a follow-up Retroactive Funding phase, emphasizing long-term impact and milestone achievement.

While facing challenges in areas such as application evaluation and project alignment guidance, the round provided valuable insights for future improvements. These include enhancing communication with potential grantees, refining the evaluation process, and improving support for project marketing. Overall, this grants round successfully funded high-potential projects while laying the groundwork for ongoing advancement in token engineering within the Optimism ecosystem, demonstrating the effectiveness of this focused, two-phase funding approach.

links.name: Token Engineering QF Grants Round: Spring 2024 GG20 Round Retro
links.description:
The Token Engineering QF Grants Round: Spring 2024 demonstrated significant impact and growth in advancing the field of token engineering. With a total distribution of $50k worth of $TEC across 32 projects, and crowdfunding of $9,365 raised from 554 unique donors, the round saw an impressive 83.3% increase in crowdfunding compared to the previous iteration. This growth extended to the number of participating projects, which rose by 60% to 32, including 23 new initiatives that more than doubled the influx of fresh ideas. The average contribution also increased substantially by 75.49% to $16.90, indicating heightened donor engagement and generosity.

The round successfully met its key objectives of supporting public good projects, encouraging innovation, and building a stronger community within the token engineering ecosystem. By funding a diverse range of projects across categories such as tooling, research, social infrastructure, and education, the round ensured a holistic advancement of the field. The implementation of the Tunable Quadratic Funding (TQF) Matching Boost and the involvement of nine seasoned advisors in the evaluation process enhanced the quality of funded projects and aligned support with genuine expertise.

Being selected as one of Gitcoin's sponsored community rounds significantly amplified the round's reach, attracting a wider array of projects and new perspectives. This expanded visibility, coupled with the round's focus on long-term impact assessment, has laid a strong foundation for the continued growth and maturation of the token engineering field. Grantees expressed appreciation for the trust and platform provided, while the lessons learned from this round will inform improvements for future iterations. Overall, the Token Engineering QF Grants Round: Spring 2024 marks a significant milestone in fostering innovation, supporting diverse projects, and engaging a growing community of contributors in the advancement of token engineering principles and practices.

links.name: Results of Token Engineering Grants Round 2
links.description:
The Token Engineering (TE) Grants Program concluded its second Quadratic Funding (QF) round as part of the Gitcoin Beta Round, which ran from August 15 to 29. This round was featured on Gitcoin and funded by TEC's Common Pool. The round had been configured with a $25,000 matching pool, a 20% matching cap, and a 2x coefficient multiplier for the TE Matching Boost.

The round saw significant engagement, with 14 projects participating and attracting 1,837 unique donors. A total of 2,608 contributions were made, raising $5,786.48 from donors, with an average contribution of $3.15. The top-performing project was the Bonding Curve Research Group (BCRG), which received 9,710.0293 $TEC. Other notable projects included DataBites (7,073.6435 $TEC), Dynamic Optimization Algorithm for Self-regulating Tokenomics (6,982.7264 $TEC), Commons Stack (6,044.8391 $TEC), and Index Wallets (5,533.4081 $TEC). In total, the round distributed 48,550.1464 $TEC across all participating projects.

links.name: TEC OP Migration
links.description:
The Token Engineering Commons (TEC) successfully completed its migration from Gnosis to Optimism (OP) Mainnet, aligning itself with Optimism's mission of scaling Ethereum and funding public goods. This move positioned TEC among like-minded entities dedicated to solving similar challenges in the blockchain ecosystem.

As part of the migration, TEC tokens for regular EOA holders were transferred to the same addresses on OP Mainnet. The TEC's Augmented Bonding Curve (ABC) switched from using xDai to Rocket Pool ETH (rETH) as collateral, linking the TEC token's value to this staked ETH derivative. New contract addresses were established for the TEC token (0x8fc7c1109c08904160d6ae36482b79814d45eb78), Common Pool (0xb941365430a16659658bb23b88efaede1d839354), and Reserve Pool (0xae34eb7c3163aad32142fbbcf15ec234c9ef173f).

The migration process also addressed special cases, including the consolidation of Lasertag's inactive assets into the Common Pool and the conversion of the Reward Board's wxDAI to rETH. These changes marked a significant step for the TEC community, setting the stage for continued growth and collaboration within the Optimism ecosystem.

links.name: TEC Dashboard
links.description: The dashboard showcases a comprehensive view of the TEC ecosystem. It displays crucial market information, including the market price of $TEC-$OP, along with sell and buy prices. The dashboard features prices for all SAMM TEC pairs and a TEC Price Chart for visual representation. It also tracks community engagement metrics such as the number of unique holders, their growth over time, and holder distribution. The TEC Coordination team's activities are transparent, with the dashboard showing transactions and balances of their multisig on the Optimism network. Financial health indicators are present through the $TEC Common and Reserve Pool Balances. The dashboard includes TEC ABC Attributes, specifically focusing on Mint and Burn Tributes paid in rETH. Lastly, it provides data on $TEC token trades, offering a holistic view of the token's market activity and liquidity.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Using our OP Retro funding, we raised $115K from the Gitcoin network to fund OP governance (and other) projects and test a novel governance mechanism for OP. Tunable Quadratic Funding (â€œTQFâ€) engaged OP delegates and citizens in Quadratic Funding allocation decisions for funding OP ecosystem development.

We experimented with TQF in two Gitcoin rounds, demonstrating its ability to incorporate OP badgeholder and delegate preferences into QF allocations for externally-raised capital. In Spring 2024, we incorporated an OP delegate signal, as a test in amplifying OP voices. In August, we refined the OP TQF signals, which shifted normal QF distributions by $16,205 (53.8%) and focused them on 12 projects with strong ties to the OP ecosystem and its governance. 

Finally, this project demonstrated an ability to integrate OP community-driven preferences with Subject Matter Expert priorities, which we believe is a useful contribution to OP capital allocation and broader governance decisions.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The above work broadly benefited the Superchain by attracting token engineering projects and expertise to the ecosystem. Interestingly, many of the projects with the greatest TQF boosts also contributed specifically to OP capital allocation and broader governance capacity:

- **Pairwise (94% boost):** Governance voting dApp optimizing decision-making and RetroPGF processes.

- **GovGraph (169% boost):** Visualizes relationships between OP governance participants, enhancing transparency.

- **Superchain Innovation Research (121% boost):** Research on Superchain tokenomics and governance.

- **Breadchain Cooperative (63% boost):** PGF DAI mechanisms for community-driven funding.

- **Inverter Network (53% boost):** Token programmability stack & no-code deployment panel, lowering barriers for token systems on OP.

- **EVMcrispr (47.1% boost):** Simplifies smart contract interactions on EVM chains, making them more accessible.

name: Retro 4 Metrics: Trusted User Models and OpenRank Trusted User Model
description:
[WHAT WE DID]

Retro 4 pioneered the experiment of impact metrics, amongst which is the importance of defining valuable users interacted with applications on the superchain. Trusted User Model was introduced to measure the count of users qualified for the Trusted User definition. 

Several data sources were used to compose the Trusted User definition. The Farcaster user reputation scores computed by OpenRank on an curated engagement graph was used as one of the three major data sources, next to FIDs and Gitcoin Passport. 

The reputation scores are taken from OpenRank Farcaster Global Profile Ranking: Farcaster users are basically categorized into the two strategies: [**following**](https://docs.openrank.com/integrations/farcaster/global-profile-ranking#strategy-following) and [**engagement](https://docs.openrank.com/integrations/farcaster/global-profile-ranking#strategy-engagement), and ranked recursively by incoming and outgoing trusted engagement signals such as recast, comment, likes on their social graph.** This score is made available, open-sourced and verifiable by OpenRank reputation protocol.

[OUR IMPACT]

Users which rank high on OpenRank scores are acknowledged lost of developers as highly likely to be reputable real users instead of spam, Sybils and scammers. 

https://gov.optimism.io/t/retro-funding-4-impact-metrics-a-collective-experiment/8226
Additionally, Retro 4 also used a metric called OpenRank Trusted User Model, which indicates an even tougher-defined trust. Therefore it is a good metric to measure the contribution of an app on Optimism. 

[WHAT IS OpenRank]

OpenRank is a decentralized ranking and reputation protocol. It enables a verifiable reputation compute layer for the open web that unlocks a broad range of useful applications, including those that resist cryptographic or game-theoretic mechanisms of trust. Using graph compute algorithms like EigenTrust, it offers resilience from sybil contexts, provides scalable and context-specific compute, and enables permissionless access to compute and reputation data for any user.

Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
We made possible 2 metrics in Retro 4 round for onchain builders. 

The key idea is to count users for onchain applications in a meaningful way, which has a high interest in getting users who are not likely spam and Sybils but reputable real users. 

OpenRank's user reputation via Farcaster engagement graph was employed in two different ways that generate two trusted user metrics. The highly ranked Farcaster users according to OpenRank, are highly regarded as reputable real users by Farcaster developer community.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
We would say that the direct beneficiaries are voters, as they can make better decisions easier, and the indirect but most important beneficiary is the Optimism governance collective itself. 

This first iteration also opens further avenues to improve the Trusted User Model in the near future.

name: Delegate Match
description: Delegate Match is a Farcaster frame that helps users find Optimism Delegates who match their vision and values in a simple, fun, and fast way by answering 11 multiple-choice questions. The goal is to increase the votable supply of OP by allowing anyone to find an aligned delegate easily in Farcaster and funnel them to delegate or redelegate to active delegates.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The **Delegate Match Farcaster Frame** is designed to improve accessibility in Optimism governance by helping OP token holders find active delegates who align with their values and vision. The tool streamlines the process, allowing users to take an 11-question survey and match with active, values-aligned delegates, increasing the overall votable OP supply. [Landing page](https://delegatematch.xyz/)

Leveraging Farcasterâ€™s 650K registered users and 60-100K daily active users, Delegate Match boosts exposure to the OP delegation process. Our Farcaster Frame provides a seamless experience, enabling users to make an informed decision and delegate their tokens in just five minutes. By integrating the Ethereum Attestation Service, Delegate Match supports delegate reputation-building. It provides OP holders and delegates a low-cost, high-impact, innovative delegation tool. [Onchain Metrics](https://hackmd.io/@Suede/rJaRn0UJJe)

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The main beneficiaries of **Delegate Match** are OP token holders who arenâ€™t too engaged in governance and OP delegates with active delegations. Holders can easily find and delegate or redelegate to active delegates who align with their values. OP delegates, particularly underrepresented ones, benefit from increased visibility to grow their delegations based on values alignment rather than popularity. By encouraging broader participation, Delegate Match helps decentralize governance and promotes greater equity among delegates, enabling them to play a more meaningful role in Optimism's decision-making.

We have a solid foundation and are passionately engaged in exploring innovative solutions in this uncharted territory. Our impact included critical inquiries into user experience, impact tracking, and outreach strategies so that delegation is informed, accessible, accountable, and efficient for all stakeholders. Delve into our [Vision and Insights](https://hackmd.io/@Suede/HJaVrJw1ye)

name: Self-Serve Developer Ranking platform
description:
[WHAT WE DID]

This web app https://devrankings.openrank.com/ enables any community or project to create your own Developer and Github repository rankings, using Github developer activity graph. The GitHub data is public from by Open Source Observer. The ranking and reputation compute is permissionless and verifiable, powered by OpenRank Protocol. Communities can leverage this tool to generate developer and repo reputation scores given their own seed trust. 

This tool helps everyone to have a quick understanding of how the developer and repo reputation scores are generated, through the step-by-step process of selecting ranking criteria, seed trust peers, and strength of seed trust peersâ€™ opinion influencing the reputation score of the rest of the peers. 

[OUR IMPACT]

The web app is powered by a graph of relevant GitHub event data from Open Source Observer, covering more than 2,000 organizations and over 30,000 code repositories, was employed in generating these scores. We established two kinds of peers: GitHub users and repositories. We then used a variation of EigenTrust, the Hubs and Authorities algorithm, which computes rankings on an asymmetric bipartite trust graph. 

The web app made it possible to generate client-side compute results, and replicate the same computation used in Retro 5, therefore it also serves as an educational and accountability tool for Optimism collective to better understand the governance metrics and algos used in a verifiable and transparent way. 

[WHAT IS OpenRank]

OpenRank is a decentralized ranking and reputation protocol. It enables a verifiable reputation compute layer for the open web that unlocks a broad range of useful applications, including those that resist cryptographic or game-theoretic mechanisms of trust. Using graph compute algorithms like EigenTrust, it offers resilience from sybil contexts, provides scalable and context-specific compute, and enables permissionless access to compute and reputation data for any user.

links.name: Web App Tool
links.description: This web app  enables any community or project to create your own Developer and Github repository rankings, using Github developer activity graph. This tool helps everyone to have a quick understanding of how the developer and repo reputation scores are generated, through the step-by-step process of selecting ranking criteria, seed trust peers, and strength of seed trust peersâ€™ opinion influencing the reputation score of the rest of the peers.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
This is an additional tool to provide transparency and early verifiability of the reputation scores that OpenRank has generated for repos and developers in Retro 5, using Github activity data. 

The web app made it possible to generate client-side compute results, and replicate the same computation used in Retro 5, therefore it also serves as an educational and accountability tool for Optimism collective to better understand the governance metrics and algos used in a verifiable and transparent way.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
We would say the direct beneficiaries are governance participants and community members, because they can access transparency and accountability using this tool. And the ultimate beneficiary is Optimism governance collective itself. 

Also as an variant usage of this tool, any project community can use this tool to create custom rankings of developers and repos in their own context, therefore this tool is also a public good for the whole Optimism community.

name: DeVouch powered by Giveth
description:
Giveth is an open-source, radically transparent, user-friendly donation platform that supports and verifies public goods projects, enabling them to raise crypto with zero added fees and no intermediaries. Today, Giveth supports donations on OP Mainnet, Ethereum Mainnet, Base, Celo, as well as 7 other chains, and several OP Governance projects, such as growthepie, DAOstar, Pairwise, Praise & EAS raise funds on our platform.

Recently, in coordination with the Optimism Token House, we launched DeVouch, a system for members of reputable organizations in the Ethereum ecosystem to vouch for projects looking to raise funding. It was created with special attention to the Optimism Retro Funding mechanism.

How does it work?

By vouching for a project, the organization can lend its credibility to the project, building confidence for those looking to support it with funding.

DeVouch collects projects from Gitcoin, Giveth, and Optimism Retro Funding rounds and showcases them in a single place, allowing all users to either vouch for or flag each project. Visitors to the website can see the vouches and flags received by each project, which were tracked by the "Attester Group" that the vouch or flag came from. 

Attester Groups are formed by looking at on-chain Attestation Data from EAS on Optimism to know who belongs to which organization or community sub-set by which Attestations have been issued to them and by whom. An example of Attester Groups are RetroFunding 5 voters or Gitcoin passport holders.

This allows members of these groups to lend their reputation to the project looking for funding. However, attesting with DeVouch is a double-edged sword, if a project seems suspicious or untrustworthy then they could also receive a flag, warning others to think twice before supporting this project.

DeVouch is open-source and allows any platform or individual to query DeVouch data using our graphQL API as well as contribute by the issuance of attestations using the DeVouch schema. Anyone can also add their Attester Group to DeVouch by making a simple PR on the DeVouch Github Repository

Who uses it?

DeVouch was launched in early June 2024, and has been featured as additional tooling in Retro Funding 5. Giveth is also integrating it to provide Decentralized Verification of projects seeking funding on the platform.

Considering that we launched on June 12th of this year, the over 700 onchain attestations thatâ€™ve happened through DeVouch before September 18th shows that there are good expectations, regarding the growth of users.

Also, to map potential, we look at the demand for such a service, and specifically with Optimism, we have over 591 projects (according to Alchemy) between dApps, dexes, etc., which are all looking to take fundraising opportunities and a piece of the $3.3B in Public Goods funding that was set aside by the Optimism Collective. 

A decentralized vouching system is essential to bringing more efficiency to allocating funds, as well as to map the reputation of each project by the entire Optimism Community. Is a project a scam? Flag it! Is a project legit? Vouch for it!

Giveth is known for its ability to support projects in their fundraising effort, and yes from October 2023 until September 18th 2024 we facilitated nearly $1M of donations to projects on our platform, and rewarded donors via our GIVbacks program. But our efforts to verify projects are legitimate is often forgotten. With DeVouch, we are decentralizing this effort and enabling other programs, especially in the Superchain, to also verify that the projects applying for funding are legitimate.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Since Givethâ€™s launch of DeVouch in June until Sep 18th, there were over 700 attestations made, with over 150 being for projects in Retro Funding 4 & 5. Our modular tool allows anyone to lend their credibility to projects that are applying for RetroFunding rounds, as well as fundraising on Gitcoin & Giveth. 

DeVouch is built in a modular way that allows any grant program to add their projects & any attestor groups to add their reputation. Our default UI allows badgeholders to see in a glance how many people of relevant reputation vouch for the project; e.g. you can quickly see that 2 RF4 Badgeholders, 3 OP Delegates, 11 Gitcoin Passport Holders, 1 RF5 Voter, & 1 Giveth Verifier all [vouched for EAS](https://devouch.xyz/?source=rf5).

Every project that applied to RF4 & RF5, even those that were rejected, were able to be vouched for, or flagged during the review period. Many of the rejected projects were accurately flagged by the community on DeVouch.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The OP community (esp. delegates) can support projects that are adding value to the Superchain Community. While unable to participate in Retro Funding directly, through DeVouch, they can lend their credibility to them, and leave a comment about the project using our extremely easy to use UX. [Try it out!](https://devouch.xyz/?source=rf6)

Voters & reviewers in Retro Funding programs are able to incorporate the wisdom of the crowds. 

We helped the Foundation prevent imposters. DeVouch made tweets tagging every project that applied in RF5. If impersonation occurred, the project would have seen the tweet, flagged it on DeVouch and reported it.

Projects have a simple way to prove their legitimacy in an industry ripe with scams. Giveth also ran 9 QF rounds (7 hosted on Superchain networks), raising over [$865k for projects](https://giveth.io/qf-archive) like EAS, Pairwise & growthepie alongside projects that are making irl impact like Palestine Children's Relief Fund or the EFF.

name: Optimism Governance in Costa Rica
description:
Inbest has been a leader in the region for Optimism Governance, focused on delivering Web3 education in Spanish and establishing Optimism's presence in Costa Rica since 2023. We've actively contributed to the Superchain and its governance model. The country's first university blockchain course about optimism governance, was created by InBest,  as part of a Token House mission we applied for and successfully completed: [Integrate Optimism Governance into University Module].
.

We have been leading especially in S5 and S6, through Inbest-sponsored OP Days events, talks at universities, workshops, digital content, and more. Thanks to this S5's mission to integrate Optimism governance into university modules, we've sparked interest across students, users, and major universities.
.

P.S.: The team received no compensation, and all events and expenses were covered by Inbest.

links.name: Optimism Governance into University modules
links.description:
The first university module on blockchain technology at a national level was made possible thanks to optimism, and to our prior knowledge, experience, relationships, work, and support from the grants council. 
.     

I, Alberto, team leader at InBest and educator at CENFOTEC University (agalan@ucenfotec.ac.cr), initiated the application for this mission, bringing the opportunity to CENFOTEC students. It's important to note that not only CENFOTEC students were accepted but also students from other universities, the course was held at CENFOTEC's facilities. 
.     

Thanks to this win-win collaboration, CENFOTEC positioned itself as a tech leader in the region and attracted new attention, while Optimism established itself in Costa Rica as a growing ecosystem with many opportunities.
.     

However, it was thanks to the joint effort of the InBest team that all of this was possible. The team dedicated countless hours to research, work, creating contacts, and everything necessary to make this a reality. On behalf of the entire Costa Rican community, we are immensely grateful to the Optimism Foundation and the grants committee for trusting us with this responsibility, and to CENFOTEC University for fully supporting the initiative. Special thanks to all the team contributors as well.
.    

To avoid overwhelming this message with numerous links, weâ€™ve decided to publish a single link to the Optimism governance forum, where everything is meticulously documentedâ€”dates, links, photos, videos, contracts, and more.
.    

This two-month course consisted of four modules and 13 sessions, with four educators covering their areas of expertise. The course included assignments, quizzes, exams, and a final group project!
.    

We also took the initiative to organize a small hackathon called "From Costa Rica to the Superchain," where students competed in Jocke Race and prepared a short pitch for the forum. Specific details about this will be covered in a separate section.
.     

100% of the funds received from the Growth Grant were distributed among the students. All additional expenses, such as promotion, software, gas fees, content creation, etc., were covered by InBest. It is important to mention that none of the educators or special guests received any compensation for their time or preparation for the classes. Details on how student rewards were distributed, including addresses, links, and on-chain proof, are documented in the linked forum post.
.     

Thanks to these efforts, we are now in contact with other universities that are taking notice of what's happening.
.    

Everything has been documented and is publicly available for anyone to replicate.

links.name: From Costa Rica to the Superchain
links.description:
"From Costa Rica to the Superchain" is an initiative that emerged from the university module. We organized a small hackathon for the students, where they had to pitch their projects in a virtual meeting to both peers and teachers, followed by a fun joke race!
.     

Each project had to include an MVP with a contract deployed on OPsepolia. this was made to incentivize students to part take, work as a team, and to create projects and apply to hackathons, grants or missions requests. The presented projects were:
.    

- Merkle Tree Airdrop.  

- Web3 Affiliate Marketing.  

- Web3 Grades Manager.  

- Fitness Dapp.  

- Web3 Bets.  

- Decentralized WAZE.  

- Superchain Donations.  

- Web3 Gaming.  

.   

Full details of each project can be found in the forum post.
.      

Even though the module and all sessions were conducted in Spanish, we held this hackathon in English, pushing students to pitch in English as well. This was done to prepare them for future opportunities, most of which are in English like the missions request, and to take them out of their comfort zones. It was encouraging to see students with limited English skills successfully present their projects and even post them on the governance forum as short video pitches.
.       

Some participants have applied to missions, others joined the Superchain hackathon, while others are now involved in the Base Latam hackathon.

links.name: CharmVerse Mission Grant
links.description:
Here is the initial application for the mission request. We only asked for 2,500 OP tokens, with 100% of those tokens allocated as rewards for the students. with 100 OP tokens per graduated student. We intentionally kept the reward low to avoid attracting people solely for the tokens. Our goal was to engage those genuinely interested in learning about Optimism.
.       

Although Ignacio Trejos was listed as the team lead in the initial application, it was Alberto GalÃ¡n from Inbest [agalan@ucenfotec.ac.cr], a CENFOTEC educator, who led the initiative.
.       

This was discussed with the Grant Council prior to applying, as the university lacked the expertise to run the course independently. The Inbest team took full responsibility for the execution of the program.
.         

No compensation was provided to the team.

links.name: OP Day
links.description:
To avoid sharing numerous links for every event, we've decided to publish the links to the governance forum where all progress has been properly documented with the dates.
.      
 
In this forum topic, you'll find everything related to the OP Day initiative created by InBest. It began at the start of 2024 with the goal of growing the OP community in the country and educating people about Optimism governance, its technology, and the superchain.
.   
 
- [In FEBRUARY]  we hosted a special Valentineâ€™s Day event featuring Optimism Red, targeting local communities. We invited CRIPTOCANTINA, to bring the Optimism ecosystem to them and showcase its opportunities. With around 50 attendees, we covered topics like an introduction to Optimism, governance, grants, RPGF, and OP airdrops for users. We also ran a "learn to earn" game with OP tokens as rewards. The event's expenses, such as the venue, decoration, and food, were covered by the InBest team. We also created videos and photos to promote it on social media. everything is on the forum.
.     
 
During this OP initiative, we onboarded Robert, founder of CheckMyTicket (now Hallos.io), who migrated from Polygon and Arbitrum to the Optimism mainnet. Heâ€™s now a key figure in the Base LatAm initiative. This first event served as a test, and we issued NFT tickets to all attendees. Full details are available on the forum post.
.    
  
- [In MARCH], we held a virtual OP Day focused on governance and missions. It was a smaller event tailored to builders, and the idea to integrate Optimism governance into local university courses was born here. We had Pumbi, an Optimism ambassador, as a special guest, and the event was hosted on Hallos via the OP mainnet. CRIPTOCANTINA also applied for a growth mission afterward, though it wasnâ€™t approved this time. Links to the presentation and NFTs are on the forum.
.     
  
In addition to the virtual event, we also had a March event at CENFOTEC University, marking the first introduction of the OP ecosystem to a university. This laid the foundation for CENFOTEC becoming the home of the first blockchain university module in the country. Full details are on the forum post.
.    
  
- [In APRIL], we headed to Sendero on the east side with ASOBLOCKCHAIN to invite their community. Alfredo Brolag led the presentation, and we partnered with Hallos.io to issue NFTs to attendees. At this event, Optimism's new intents for the next governance seasons were announced, and we highlighted these opportunities for our communities. I also announced my role as a delegate and invited attendees to participate in Token House governance. This event was also sponsored by InBest. Pictures, details, and NFTs are on the forum.
.    
  
- [In MAY], we continued with the mission of bringing the Superchain to local communities. This time, we were invited to present at Telescoped, a community of Web2 developers. We introduced Optimism governance, grant missions, and RPGF opportunities to a new audience of developers in Costa Rica. The presentation was filmed and published on our YouTube channel to broaden its impact ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HIae-YbSdxk&list=PLjbGiMPlmBjsya5a8HMIKqaAnaurtUpZT&index=3&t=181s ). 
All the links, videos, pictures, and the presentation are documented on the forum.
.    
  
- [In JUNE], we prepared for the mission to integrate governance into university modules. Alongside Robert, I presented at UNA, one of the countryâ€™s major universities, on blockchain technology and opportunities in the superchain. We invited attendees to sign up for the upcoming university module in CENFOTEC University, which helped achieve a 100% success rate since we were focusing on tech students and not just promoting the module with anyone who just wanted quick rewards in OP. Full details, links, and pictures are on the forum.
.   
   
- [in JULY and AUGUST] we did not host OPDays, we were dedicated to the Optimism University Module at CENFOTEC, which will be covered separately.
.   
   
- [In SEPTEMBER], we hosted another OP Day to maintain momentum after the university module. We held a graduation party for the 25 students who completed the module at Nucleo Sabana rooftop in the heart of San JosÃ©, with food and drinks. We also gave a brief presentation to continue educating the community. sponsored by inbest. Links, pictures, and all details are on the forum.
.    
   
- [in OCTOBER]: TBA.
.  
  
This year the Main ETH Event is using hallos.io on base chain to register the attendants and sell the tickets, this year the event will be hosted in CENFOTEC as a result of the relationship we have been growing, we have given discounts to the holders of the OP Day and the University Module NFTs, showcasing the use case of NFT ticketing and incentivizing holders to attend.
.   
  
To support and complement our physical events and increase our reach, we have continued creating digital content to educate our growing audience on Optimism governance through InBest channels. For example, we drew inspiration for this video from one made in English by OP Michael: 
.  
  
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H91b6a9duxA&list=PLjbGiMPlmBjsya5a8HMIKqaAnaurtUpZT&index=2&t=224s

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
Successfully integrated optimism governance into Costa Rica University modules completing the token house governance growth mission titled [Integrate Optimism Governance into University Module], and hosted governance workshops, community calls, and events [OPDays] throughout the year for Seasons 5 (S5) and 6 (S6).
.  
  
P.S.: This was a growth mission, and all tokens were distributed among the students. No compensation has yet been provided to the team. All OPDays were sponsored by inbest.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
We successfully completed a significant governance growth mission, positioning Optimism as the first university-level blockchain course in Costa Rica.
.  
  
We organized gov workshops, community calls, and events throughout the year [OP Days] This initiative has increased participation in governance, missions, and on the forum.
.  
  
Our efforts have enhanced the governance process by fostering community engagement and education within the Optimism ecosystem in the country, through the "Integrate Optimism Governance into University Module" mission and the OPDays. Not to mention that this module can now be replicated anywhere anytime. Our work is now attracting attention from other universities and organizations
.  
  
By facilitating hands-on experiences, we empowered users and students to participate and collaborate, enriching the governance framework with diverse perspectives.
.  
  
Creating the next generation of Optimism leaders, and ensuring a robust future for the ecosystem!

name: Retro Funding & Token House API
description:

This backend and API is leveraged by both software built by Agora (Retrofunding sign up and identity management), but also "official" voting apps built by Optimism grantees like Gitcoin/RG and Charmvese, as well as community apps like Retrolist, RetroPGFHub, Delegatematch.xyz, IDriss, opdelegate.com, Tally, Curia, 3dns, Metric Garden, Open Source Observer, and more.

Note â€“ all of Agora's projects are being worked on by our full team of 12 (viewable here https://www.agora.xyz/#About) Contributors listed on our projects are only the admins involved in completing our profile and do not represent the full headcount involved in projects.
