impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The Retrofunding & Token House API (https://vote.optimism.io/api_v1) powers the R4 and R5 official voting interfaces (https://round5.optimism.io/). It serves the data that powers the voting app, receives ballot submissions, and manages the updates to EAS.

On top of powering the main voting UI of retrofunding, this API is also used by a plethora of community applications such as: Retrolist, RetroPGFHub, Delegatematch.xyz, IDriss, opdelegate.com, Tally, Curia, 3dns, Metric Garden, Open Source Observer, and more.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Voting app builders: this API is used by the teams who build the voting UI for each round,

Citizens who vote on RF: when citizens vote with the voting UI, they are leverage this API.

Community app builders: community builders use this API to pull data on both Retro Funding, and the Token House.

name: Retro 5 Metrics: Trusted Github Contributors/Stars/Forks
description:
[What WE DID]

5 impact metrics were introduced in Retro 5 to give additional information on the repo reputation, or quality indication for voters to make informed decisions. We used the same algorithm used for guest voter selection, but utilize the scores differently to create repo reputations. For example, instead of number of forks, voters can see the number of forks by reputable developers, and they can see the weighted and aggregated reputation scores of all developers who forked this repo. https://gov.optimism.io/t/impact-metrics-for-retro-funding-5/8931
TL;DR 1min video walk through: https://www.loom.com/share/92ccf283b670477d9bf147f8b66a22e3?sid=9fcf321f-8dd3-4ba7-8221-8a301b9b15d3

[OUR IMPACT] 

Now we have reputation scores for 47K repos in Github for their contribution to OP Stack core repos. And these scores are readily available for any developer in OP ecosystem to use.

Introducing reputation metrics is important because 1) voters need better signals to know if a repo is contributing to OP stack and to what degree is that contribution; 2) voters need signals to know if a repo has been interacted by reputable developers, which adds to an underlying endorsement of the value of the repos. 

More on our work: https://x.com/SahilDewan/status/1839701853258530864

[WHAT IS OpenRank]

OpenRank is a decentralized ranking and reputation protocol. It enables a verifiable reputation compute layer for the open web that unlocks a broad range of useful applications, including those that resist cryptographic or game-theoretic mechanisms of trust. Using graph compute algorithms like EigenTrust, it offers resilience from sybil contexts, provides scalable and context-specific compute, and enables permissionless access to compute and reputation data for any user.

ventureFunding.details: Seed round of Karma3 Labs

subcategory: Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
We made possible 5 impact metrics in Retro 5 to give additional information on the repo reputation, or quality indication for voters to make informed decisions.

Using a web-of-trust approach, the metrics were generated from a reputation graph created on Github activities. These metrics are trust-weighted, and have served voters in Retro round 5 to better understand the quality and reputation of a given repo, beyond just traditional stars/forks/contributors numbers, which are not Sybil-resistant.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: Upon early feedbacks, these metrics are good predictors of repo impact towards OP Stack. We would say that the direct beneficiaries are voters, as they can make better decisions easier, and the indirect but most important beneficiary is the Optimism governance collective itself.

name: DAOstar
description:
DAOstar is the non-profit standards body for DAOs. We build important public goods that make DAOs more transparent and interoperable. Our contributions to OP Collective include: 
- maintenance and upgrades to EIP-4824 infrastructure. EIP-4824 creates a global source of truth that is owned and managed by a DAO. Through our efforts, we helped publish and maintain a EIP-4824 compliant daoURI for OP Collective. 
- To make the compliance easier, we also built two additional EIP-4824 adoption pathways, through ENS txt records and EAS attestations. 
- development of DAO Attestation Registry, a website for listing DAO-related schemas deployed on EAS
- several other initiatives to address the common pain points of OP Collective and other DAOs, including regulatory interoperability and access to underrepresented markets like Asia.

github.name: DAOstar repository
github.description: Contains code related to EIP-4824 registration factories, indexers, daoURI templates & reference implementations; list of all DAOIPs; DAO Attestation framework, documentation; and deployments.

grants.details: Builder grant involving the development of an attestation list schema specifically designed for DAOs, a web platform for displaying attestations made using this schema to any address, and the necessary infrastructure for deploying new instances of the platform.
EIP-4824: Governance standards for the Optimism ecosystem

links.name: DAO NYC
links.description: Organized DAO NYC in collaboration with Metagov and the Decentralization Research Center, bringing together key thinkers and practitioners (including Optimism) across the DAO ecosystem.

links.name: EIP-4824 Adoption by Optimism Collective (registration contract)
links.description: The Optimism Foundation deployed an EIP-4824 registration contract on Optimism mainnet, publishing a daoURI for the collective. This creates a single source of truth on the OP Collective, including data on governance proposals, delegates, contracts and documentation. Here is the published daoURI: https://ipfs.io/ipfs/Qmcqo4jTGrBxHxUXViWu7Z3NzucDk7y1RZZPjGJzswU8SZ

links.name: EIP-4824 Adoption by Optimism Collective (using EAS)
links.description: The Optimism Foundation published a daoURI for the OP collective, using the EIP-4824 schema deployed on EAS in Optimism mainnet. This creates a single source of truth on the OP Collective, including data on governance proposals, delegates, contracts and documentation. The reason for publishing daoURI via multiple sources (EAS and registration contract) is to showcase the ease of adopting the standard, and to test out the different adoption pathways available for all DAOs on Optimism. Here is the published daoURI: https://ipfs.io/ipfs/Qmcqo4jTGrBxHxUXViWu7Z3NzucDk7y1RZZPjGJzswU8SZ

links.name: DAO Schema Registry on EAS

The registry is deployed on Optimism mainnet. The specification can be found here: https://github.com/metagov/daostar/blob/main/DAOIPs/daoip-7.md

links.description: Built a proof-of-concept web-app that makes it easy for projects to adopt DAOIP-7 standard. All attestations are issued on Optimism, through the schema registry listed above.

links.name: Snapshot's EIP-4824 Integration
links.description: We enhanced Snapshot's EIP-4824 membersURI and proposalsURI to include more detailed information about a DAO's members and proposals. This upgrade enriches the daoURI of all DAOs in the Optimism ecosystem that rely on Snapshot.

links.name: State of DAOs Report focused on Asia
links.description: DAOstar worked with writers and communities embedded in Japan, Singapore, Taiwan, Korea amd Greater China on reports to cover the state of DAOs in Asia. Our findings pave a way forward for local communities to collaborate with global DAOs like Optimism to scale localized impact.

links.name: The DAO Policy Trilemma
links.description: This report, authored at DAOstar by the top experts on DAO regulation, makes two core recommendations to jurisdictions considering on how to address the policy issues and opportunities of DAOs. It will be incredible beneficial to the Optimism Collective, as well as other DAOs on Optimism, as the piece encourages jurisdictions to set suitable passive criteria for DAO legal recognition rather than requiring a DAO to actively register in their jurisdiction. DAOs often already publish verifiable, registration-like data through interfaces like EIP-4824. They should be able to use this data to prove their default legal status.

links.name: Legislative hearings on proposed DAO laws, Japan
links.description: Joni Pirovich, lead of the regulatory interoperability working group within DAOstar, appeared at the Japanese legislative hearings on proposed DAO laws in March 2024 on behalf of DAOstar, and helped bring additional context on DAOs to the hearing.

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
- Data interoperability and transparency within the Collective: The Optimism Collective is one of the largest DAOs, with new artifacts being released continuously. Through EIP-4824, we have created an on-chain (and off-chain) source of truth on the Optimism Collective. New artifacts can be continuously added to the Collective's daoURI, making it comprehensive over time. 

- Better visibility for DAO-related EAS schemas on Optimism: Currently, there is no place where DAO-related EAS schemas can be listed and indexed, along with a description and additional context. We built a proof-of-concept DAO Schema Registry.

- Visibility into grants. Working with OSO and Gitcoin, we have developed an initial data lake for grants across Web3, including Optimism's grants, combating grant farming and double dipping across ecosystems.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
- Governance tooling providers: More transparency and interoperability of data direclty benefit Snapshot, Snapshot X, and a variety of other governance tools, who utilize EIP-4824 to publish and handle DAO metadata.

- New participants of the OP Collective: the daoURI is a useful piece of infrastructure for anyone who'd like to find info at a single location.

- Delegates: More data transparency and standardization makes it easier for even high-context individuals to assess changes across the scope of a wide, decentralized organization.

- Grantees: Our work on grants management improves the odds of genuine projects' access to capital. It also helps the Optimism Collective reward contributions more efficiently.

name: Praise
description:
Praise is an open-source reputation and rewards system designed to recognize, track, and verify community contributions across decentralized ecosystems. By offering simple tools that integrate with both Discord and Farcaster, Praise empowers communities to mint on-chain attestations and cultivate identity and reputation.
Through peer recognition on platforms Discord and more recently Farcaster, Praise enables users to acknowledge contributions, whether large or small, and reward them with verifiable on-chain attestations. These attestations, built on Ethereum Attestation Service (EAS), are seamlessly minted and integrated into usersâ€™ decentralized identities and reputation.

grants.details:
https://gov.optimism.io/t/final-improving-governance-accessibility-through-praise-and-contribution-based-attestations/6150/32?u=parrachia

https://optimism.givepraise.xyz/

pricingModelDetails: Everything for Praise is free, but the Farcaster attestation minting. Users can give praise and receive feedback from the bot both on Discord and Farcaster. The explorer website is also completely free to use. The contract charges 0.00003 ETH (~$0.07) each time a user mints an attestation using the Farcaster frame.

name: Code of Conduct Council S5
description:
In S5, the Code of Conduct Council was pioneered for the first time to uphold governance standards within Optimism by enforcing the Code of Conduct, which went into effect in December 2021. Initially, the Foundation handled violation reports, and Token House delegates voted on enforcement, but this model became unsustainable as the ecosystem grew. To address concerns about impartiality and delegate discomfort in voting on violations, the Council was formed, undergoing two rescopings to refine its role.

Note: In the S5 scope for the role, it was intended that the majority of the funding be from RetroPGF. In S6, the budget was increased per member, and therefore that different team is not applying. From S5 budget: â€œEach Council member will receive a stipend of 3,000 OP at the end of the Season. As the activity level of the Code of Conduct Councils is unknown in advance (as it depends on the number of reports and disputes per Season), the majority of rewards for Code of Conduct Councils should be granted retroactively via RetroPGF.â€

subcategory: Councils, Commissions and Advisory Boards; NERD programs focused exclusively on core governance responsibilities (GovNERDs)::This includes Security Council, Grants Council, Developer Advisory Board, Code of Conduct Council, Anticapture Commission, Collective Feedback Commissions and GovNERDs.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 5: Sept 28th 2023 - May 8th 2024

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Code of Conduct Council has significantly contributed to improving the enforcement of governance standards within Optimism. By taking over the processing of Code of Conduct violation reports, the Council has streamlined enforcement, removing the burden from Token House delegates and allowing them to focus on higher-level governance matters. During Season 5, no Code of Conduct issues were escalated to the Token House, despite multiple submissions occurring during this period. 
In Season 5, the Council implemented clear processes for handling disputes, including a transparent reporting system that publishes enforcement decisions. Also, confirming and denying grant clawback requests from the grants council smooth lined the process in how teams that hadnâ€™t met their milestones would be treated. Further, initiatives like GravityDAOâ€™s conflict resolution training demonstrated the Councilâ€™s commitment to preventative measures, reducing the likelihood of violations in the first place.

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Council helped foster a more accessible and fair enforcement process that clearly laid out the framework and operations around possible community violations. As this was the first cohort involved in the Code of Conduct, all members had to also reflect not only on the duties initially assigned by the original proposal, but also the potential for improvement and limitations of the system established and its Internal Operating Procedures.
The impact and want for something like this was proven apparent by the Councilâ€™s reapproval, this time with a new budget of up to 6000 OP per member (vs 3000 OP in S5). This shift has improved governance efficiency, ensuring timely and impartial enforcement of community standards. The introduction of preventative measures, such as conflict resolution training, further supports long-term community well-being. Through these, the Council has played a crucial role in maintaining Optimismâ€™s integrity and promoting sustainable governance practices.

name: Optimism Fractal Respect Game Events
description:
Optimism Fractal is a community dedicated to fostering collaboration, awarding public good creators, and optimizing governance on the Optimism Superchain. We host weekly Respect Game events, featuring a unique onchain social game designed to foster collaboration, award public goods creators, and optimize governance on the Superchain. Between October 2023 and September 2024, we hosted 42 events where participants share their contributions to Optimism, rank each otherâ€™s impact with onchain attestations, and earn non-transferable Respect tokens.

These Respect tokens create a transparent, peer-reviewed system for measuring governance contributions and impact. Optimism Fractal events are a hub for pioneering fractal democracy on Optimism, providing a scalable model for decentralized decision-making. Through this gamified approach, we're shaping the future of Optimism governance, connecting builders, and community leaders while fostering a culture of active governance participation.

This project is for the hosting, promoting, organizing, and producing of respect game events, as well as other key processes like community engagement and facilitation of our consensus processes. It does include not the development of tools used at the events or the Optimism Town Hall events which take place after Respect Game events, as there are separate applications for these projects.

This work has not been funded by the Collective outside of the RetroPGF Round 3 grant shown below, which supported the team who started Optimism Fractal as well as our work with several other related projects. You can see Optimystics.io/projects-and-funding details on our organizationâ€™s funding and applications for related projects.

github.description: This repository aims to organize the various tools being built, used, and pioneered at Optimism Fractal Respect Game events. For more details, you can see Github.com/optimystics and Optimystics.io/tools

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Respect Game: We've refined this core process, enabling peer evaluation of governance contributions to Optimism and creating a decentralized reputation system crucial for governance.

2. Decentralized Governance Structures: Our weekly council selection and proposal review processes, based on Respect earnings, demonstrate a practical model of decentralized decision-making.

3. Governance Builder Showcases: We provide a regular forum for developers to present governance-related tools and innovations, while collaborating with others.

4. Governance Education: Our events serve as an interactive platform for newcomers to engage with innovative Optimism governance processes.

5. Stakeholder Collaboration: We foster connections between delegates, council members, and builders, creating a more cohesive governance ecosystem and facilitating knowledge exchange.

These consistent events create a stable environment for ongoing governance experimentation and refinement on Optimism.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Enhanced Governance Participation: We've increased engagement in Optimism governance by providing a regular, accessible entry point, attracting over 50 leaders to actively participate in governance practices (and many more viewers).

2. Decentralized Reputation: The Respect token earned at our events has created a nuanced measure of governance contributions, improving decision-making processes and impact measurement.

3. Governance Development: By providing a stable platform for governance experimentation and connecting participants, we've enabled the development of several open-source governance tools and inspired other communities to build on Optimism with these tools.

4. Scalable Governance Model: Our fractal approach has demonstrated how large-scale governance decisions can be made efficiently in a decentralized manner in all other aspects of Optimism governance.

These improvements have strengthened Optimism's governance, making it more effective, inclusive, and resilient.

name: OP Governance Contracts
description:
Agora built the governance contracts of the Optimism Token House. Over 70 proposals have been conducted on these contracts we've developed with an average of 8.7k voters on each vote.

Agora developed unique capabilities for the Optimism Governor such as: 
1. Approval voting for multiple choice voting, typically used funding collective intents
2. Optimistic voting, typically used for code of conduct enforcement.
3. Multiple proposal types with unique quorums and approval thresholds that conform to the Collective's operating manual.

Note â€“ all of Agora's projects are being worked on by our full team of 12 (viewable here https://www.agora.xyz/#About) Contributors listed on our projects are only the admins involved in completing our profile and do not represent the full headcount involved in projects.

github.description: This repo contains the code for all 6 versions of the Optimism Governor, which Agora has developed and maintained. The original code is based off of OZ Governor.

grants.details: Note â€“ Agora has disclosed all grants and funding received by our entire organization on every project. We ask voters to please evaluate the sum of our contributions against the sum of our funding.

pricingModelDetails:
The product is free for users (i.e. voters). Agoraâ€™s app and contracts are also MIT-licensed and free to fork and self-deploy for anyone. 

Protocols pay Agora to deploy, host, and support our software.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The OP governance contracts power the core logic of Token House voting. From Oct 1, 2023 - September 18th 2024, around 50 proposals were created and voted on by an average of 8.7k voters each. 

These proposals have ranged from critical protocol upgrades for OP like Fault Proofs to mission requests allocating millions of OP to fund the Collective's intents.

During this period, we've also introduced several major innovations to the governor that's made the OP token house uniquely capable, such as:

1. Approval voting
2. Optimistic voting
3. Proposal types to differentiate standard and supermajority votes

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Token House voters: delegates vote on proposals on the governor

OP foundation: the foundation manage creates proposals on the governor

Mission request recipients: all intents and mission requests are funded using an approval vote.

Grant council, Security Council, Developer advisory board: all committees on Optimism are appointed through the use of an approval vote.

name: Governance widget for X and Farcaster
description:
Get alerts for active Optimism Governance votes on Agora while browsing X and Farcaster.

Most of us in crypto start our days by checking social platforms. Our tool boosts governance participation by displaying active proposals in social feeds, making it easier for Delegates and Citizens to stay informed and participate in Optimism Governance. By integrating the alerts into the platforms people already use, our widget improves the accessibility of Optimismâ€™s governance infrastructure.

Powered by the Agora API, the widget pulls in the latest proposals and displays them in your main feed, as well as inside organization profiles and channels on X and Farcaster clients (Warpcast & Supercast).

The widget has been released as part of the IDriss browser extension and is available for download in the Google Chrome Store at idriss.xyz/extension (50k+ installs).

name: Party.app + Party Protocol
description:
The Party Protocol is an open-source protocol for group coordination. It provides flexible and powerful primitives for creating a shared smart contract account governed by a group of people, big or small.

Party.app is the flagship UI / app built on top. It allows groups to form a small group wallet, and large on-chain DAO, or anything in-between. Party.app has built-in functionality for crowdfunding, governance, using apps via wallet connect, buying & selling NFTs, trading tokens, chatting, and much more.

grants.details: We raised $16.4M in funding led by a16z crypto.

pricingModelDetails:
We charge $1 per mint when users mint an NFT to join a Party (DAO).

For our optional feature called distributions, which distribute ETH to all members of a Party, we charge a 2.5% fee. Users do not need to use this feature if they don't want to.

subcategory: Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The Party Protocol is an open-source protocol for on-chain group coordination. It lets anyone form a group via a smart contract. The group can crowdfund ETH and then coordinate via on-chain governance.

Every Party in the Party Protocol is a smart contract that can do anything onchain: send tokens or ETH, swap tokens via DEX, buy and sell NFTs, use apps via WalletConnect, and distribute tokens to members.

Party Protocol / Party.app is not used directly in Optimism's governance, but we think the protocol shows what a more modern, next-gen governance protocol could look like. It's meant to me both more versatile and more consumer-friendly than Compound Governor Bravo.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Users of OP Stack chains, and developers running projects on OP Stack chains. Over 100,000 unique users have used the Party Protocol across all chains, coordinating millions of dollars of funds and passings thousands of proposals within groups.

Many companies and groups that have won RPGF grants in prior rounds have actually used Party to fund and organize their own work through various initiatives. Whether they need to crowdfund resources or coordinate with their own supporters to decide on how funds are used, this is the most useful tool for spinning up a user-friendly DAO.

name: Streamlining Retro Funding Success: Hybrid Grants Management for Optimism
description:
General Magicâ€™s Grants Management (GM GM) team offers a hybrid grants management system combining human and digital tooling to streamline the Retro Funding application process. 

Our services help identify eligible projects, match them with the right Retro Funding round, and guide them in creating solid and Optimism-focused applications that contribute meaningfully to governance and public goods funding. Through this process, we effectively assist Optimism with capital allocation by ensuring that projects applying for Retro Funding are aligned with Optimismâ€™s mission and demonstrate high impact, thus directing funds toward initiatives that support the broader ecosystem.
pricingModelDetails: Depending on the size of the grant, we receive a portion of the grant as a success fee (on average ~7% of the value of the won grant).

links.name: Successful Submission - Praise RPGF3
links.description:
For the RetroPGF 3 round, we successfully supported Praise in securing funding by identifying the most impactful aspects of their work and presenting them in a compelling narrative. Our team played a crucial role in finding the right angle for Praise's application, focusing on the value of on-chain attestations and their contribution to Optimism's governance.

We emphasized Praise's integration of tools like Gitcoin Passport and Regen Score, which align with Optimismâ€™s vision for community trust and participation. Additionally, we highlighted their newly launched attestation explorer, which allows users to review community impact data, further cementing their role in Optimism Citizens' eligibility processes. The inclusion of metrics such as 100+ users, 400+ praises, and 102 Praise Optimist attestations underscored their community engagement and governance contributions, making it clear how Praise facilitates active governance participation through its data-driven reputation and rewards system. By carefully curating these elements, the application demonstrated Praiseâ€™s measurable impact and showed how their attestation feature for Optimism is pivotal to the ecosystem.

links.name: Successful Application - Giveth Web3 House RPGF3
links.description:
For RetroPGF 3, we helped Giveth Web3 House secure 49,689.64 OP by emphasizing its role as a central hub for the Optimism ecosystem. We highlighted the houseâ€™s contributions to the Developer Ecosystem, showcasing its involvement with key projects like RetroPGF, EthBarcelona 2023, and MetaCartel, as well as its support for Hermez in advancing L2 capabilities. 

Our strategy focused on the house's alignment with Optimismâ€™s mission, particularly in fostering community-driven innovation and public goods. We highlighted measurable impact, including 500 total visitors, 200 Optimism-related visitors, and 300 accommodated guests since 2019, while also emphasizing the houseâ€™s Solar Punk ethos and its role as a collaborative space for discussions and roundtables on Optimismâ€™s goals. The inclusion of key financial data, such as the $35,000 yearly maintenance cost and $200,000 in accommodation value, helped justify the funding request. By positioning Giveth House as an â€œOptimism think-tank,â€ we underscored its importance within the ecosystem, leading to the successful RetroPGF 3 outcome.

links.name: Successful Submission - Namespace Season 5 Cycle 19 Mission Request
links.description:
For the Season 5 Cycle 19 Mission Request, we played a key role in the success of Namespace by providing essential support throughout the grant application process. Our contribution began with identifying a strategic angle that aligned with the goals of Optimism's ecosystem, focusing on Namespaceâ€™s ability to supercharge ENS utility, specifically its subname management and developer toolkit offerings. In crafting the application, we emphasized how Namespace provides comprehensive tools for ENS name owners to manage and issue subnames, fostering both individual and community engagement. We also highlighted how Namespaceâ€™s technical documentation makes it easy for developers to integrate ENS subname functionality into their projects, significantly cutting down implementation time.

Our team ensured that these differentiating factors were articulated, emphasizing the project's potential for growing the Optimism ecosystem by attracting new builders and simplifying development processes. The application also detailed key metrics from testnets, showcasing Namespaceâ€™s economic impact and user engagement. This data-driven approach and the team's extensive experience with ENS demonstrated Namespaceâ€™s capacity to deliver on its promises.

links.name: Successful Application - Unitap Retro Funding 4
links.description:
For RetroPGF 4, we assisted Unitap in securing 1,540.7 OP by highlighting its critical role in simplifying the onboarding of new users into Web3 networks. Our focus was on positioning Unitap as a comprehensive solution to the challenges of user acquisition and retention in blockchain ecosystems, emphasizing its Gas Tap, Token Tap, and Prize Tap functionalities, which have been deployed on Optimism. We showcased Unitapâ€™s innovative approach to onboarding through Sybil-resistant gas token distribution, incentivized user missions, and unique token and prize distribution systems. 

The application highlighted successful proof-of-concept collaborations, such as Glo Dollar distributing tokens and prizes via Unitapâ€™s tools on Optimism, proving its utility for future growth in the Web3 space. Additionally, we supported the application by presenting key impact metrics, including 2,348 total transactions, 245 interactions from trusted Optimism users, and 110 average monthly active addresses, all of which demonstrated the platformâ€™s growing adoption. By framing Unitap as a scalable, user-friendly platform that addresses the barriers to Web3 onboarding, we ensured a successful outcome in RetroPGF 4.

links.name: Successful Application - Spearbit/Cantina Retro Funding 5
links.description:
For the Retro Funding 5 round, we assisted Spearbit/Cantina with their Cantina.xyz - OP Stack Audits application. Our approach focused on crafting a comprehensive application highlighting Cantina's established expertise in providing security audits within the Optimism ecosystem, in alignment with Optimismâ€™s goals of ensuring robust security for the OP Stack. We emphasized Cantinaâ€™s work's impact by showcasing how their security audits for critical components, such as Optimismâ€™s EAS and cross-chain functionality, contributed to the reliability and safety of the OP Stack.

Additionally, we illustrated how their continuous monitoring and incident response services supported projects like Omni-x and Decent.xyz, ensuring secure deployment and scalability across multiple chains. In preparing the application, we ensured that Cantina's pricing model and funding history were presented, which justified the need for continued funding. By structuring the application to emphasize Cantina's value as a trusted security partner in the Optimism ecosystem, we helped secure a successful outcome in Retro Funding 5.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Builder Ideas plays a crucial role in supporting Optimism Governance by providing a dedicated platform where actionable ideas for builders can be posted by the Optimism Foundation, OP Labs, Coinbase, and other core developments. This platform fosters a culture of open collaboration, empowering developers to contribute meaningfully to the collective goals of the Optimism ecosystem.

Initially, ideas were managed through GitHub Issues in the ecosystem contributions repository, which was unstructured and difficult to navigate. Developers faced challenges in discovering and submitting potential projects, which hindered engagement and contributions.

To address this, in collaboration with the Optimism Foundation, we redesigned the platform, transitioning from GitHub to a dedicated website. This move significantly improved accessibility, making it easier for developers to explore governance initiatives, submit their contributions, and enhance the overall impact of the Optimism Collective.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Our platform primarily benefits builders and developers by providing a centralized space where they can easily browse project ideas curated by the Optimism Foundation and other core development teams. By selecting ideas from the platform, developers can contribute to meaningful projects and apply for Retro Funding, creating a pathway to gain recognition and seek financial support for their projects. This fosters a more inclusive and accessible ecosystem for developer contributions.

In addition to benefiting builders, the platform significantly aids the Optimism Foundation by offering a structured way to list potential projects and track contributors willing to execute these ideas. This improved organization enables the Foundation to efficiently match talent with opportunities, ultimately boosting both the number and quality of contributions across the Superchain. The increased engagement from builders accelerates ecosystem growth and advances the goals of Optimism Governance.

It also serves as a comprehensive learning and discovery space, encapsulating historical context, scope, criteria, nominated projects, result statistics, and reflections in each round of Retro Funding. Whether you're a builder, user, or just curious about Retro Funding, this hub is your gateway to knowledge, collaboration, and community awareness.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
RetroPGF Hub serves as the central infrastructure and governance tool for Retro Funding, a vital element of the Citizens' House. It empowers the Optimism community to actively participate in governance, explore comprehensive information, and stay well-informed about all aspects of Retro Funding.

Our platform offers detailed information on Retro Funding, including its foundational concepts, the historical context of each funding round, and in-depth insights into previously funded projects. This ensures governance participants have the knowledge they need to make informed decisions.

Additionally, we enhance community engagement by providing a space for feedback on builders' project ideas. This interaction fosters a continuous learning and improvement loop that benefits both the Optimism ecosystem and the builders contributing to it.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Several users, particularly new participants in the Retro Funding process, have greatly benefited from our infrastructure. Badgeholders, key in Retro Funding governance, are a primary group that benefits. Our platform enables them to easily participate, shape Retro Funding, and access critical project data, making research and discovery more efficient for governance participants within the Citizens' House.

Our platform is also recognized as a trusted source for Retro Funding details, with referrals from platforms like retrofunding.optimism.io (Optimism Official) and optimism.curiahub.xyz (CuriaLabs), directing users to project details for each funding round. This streamlines access to key information for governance participants.

Ultimately, our platform supports governance within the Optimism ecosystem, benefiting individual users and the broader structure. Our infrastructure continues to strengthen the Citizens' House, enhancing its ability to effectively of Retro Funding.

name: Anticapture Commission [Season 5]
description: The Anticapture Commission (ACC) was born in Season 5, during which much of its current structure was defined. As a key tokenholder group within the Optimism Collective, the ACCâ€™s mandate is to prevent any single tokenholder or group from capturing control of the Token House. Comprised of high-impact delegates and Council Leads, the ACC received a 10 million OP delegation from the Governance Fund to vote on critical proposals, particularly those with Citizens' House veto rights. One of the most significant contributions during Season 5 was bringing governor upgrades to on-chain proposals after internal discussions within the ACC. This season also laid the foundation for the ACCâ€™s operating procedures and long-term role in governance.

grants.details: Active Anticapture Commission members, including the Lead and those with >50% participation on upgrade votes, received 4,000 OP (2,400 OP for first half, 1,600 OP for second half).

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 5: Sept 28th 2023 - May 8th 2024

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Anticapture Commission (ACC) was created to prevent capture of the Token House by any single tokenholder or group, including protocols and OP Chains. It represents high-impact individual delegates and acts as a communication bridge between the Token House and Citizens' House, addressing imbalances in power and maintaining governance integrity.

Relevant Documentation:
- Anticapture Commission Charter
https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission/6889
- Anticapture Commission Communication Thread
https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-communication-thread/7501
- Season 5 Retrospective
https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-retrospective-season-5/8108
- Internal Operating Procedures
https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-internal-operating-procedures/7348

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Anticapture Commission (ACC) fulfilled its Season 5 mandate by representing individual delegates and preventing capture of the Token House by any entity. It developed Internal Operating Procedures (IOP), defining voting protocols, communication methods, and reporting processes. The ACC held regular Office Hours to maintain community engagement, though no reports to the Citizens' House were required.

Key Impacts:
- Increased votable supply from 72.6M to 90M OP with a 10M OP delegation.
- 165 of 269 delegate approvals from ACC members during key cycles.
- Initiated discussions leading to on-chain governor upgrades.

Reward Split: 
A point system was used for the reward split, considering attendance at office hours, internal meetings, and voting on proposals not included in retro rewards with 20% allocated to the Lead due to the roleâ€™s extra responsibilities.

name: Snapshot
description:
Snapshot started as a voting platform designed to allow onchain organizations to vote easily without gas fees. Its strength lies in its flexibility and high customization, catering to the diverse needs of its users. This includes options for calculating users' voting power, selecting different voting mechanisms, and managing proposal and vote validation rules.

As the gas cost dropped with the maturity of L2s and the need for more decentralized and trustless voting grew, we developed Snapshot X, an onchain voting protocol. Unlike the original Snapshot, Snapshot X operates fully onchain using a set of modular smart contracts. This shift makes Snapshot censorship resistant, with onchain and cross-chain voting power computation and trustless execution, while keeping gas costs to the minimal extent possible.

subcategory: Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
We serviced the Citizens' House throughout the period of October 2023 to September 2024 with Snapshotâ€™s voting platform. Their space (https://snapshot.org/#/citizenshouse.eth) was used to facilitate the protocol veto functions through 13 proposals and 443 votes coming from 66 active voters. The Citizenâ€™s House Snapshot space gained 156 new followers throughout this period.

Beyond this, we collaborated with the Optimism Foundation and were awarded a grant to develop a cross-chain voting module. This module is designed to enable decentralized voting across OP Stack chains and could be a critical governance tool for both the Foundation and DAOs within the Superchain ecosystem in the future.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
In addition to the Citizens' House, many organizations across the Optimism and Base ecosystems have adopted Snapshot for governance. During period counting for RPGF6, on Optimism, Snapshot supported 1,085 active spaces, enabling 3,565 proposals and facilitating over 7.5 million votes from 934,550 active voters. On Base, Snapshot supported 262 spaces with 1,288 proposals, resulting in 62,475 votes from 19,591 voters. This widespread adoption positions Snapshot as the leading governance platform with the most impact within the Superchain ecosystem.

With the launch of Snapshot X, our onchain governance framework, we expect many of these users to transition from offchain to onchain voting. In particular, those using voting power from OP or Base are likely to vote on these chains, significantly increasing onchain governance activity, directly benefiting the entire Optimism Collective.

name: OP Governance Trackor
description:
I was ex governance co-lead at blockchain@USC (delegating on behalf of a16z) at the OP Collective. At the time, I realized there were no public accountability for delegates meanwhile lots of them receive huge amount of votes. And to help the collective better monitor delegates, especially the top 100 of them, I consult with people like Justine (OP head of gov), Ross (a16z), Michael Silberling (OP Data), and lots of delegates on the metrics to track for governance. 

Thus, I created 2 public dune dashboards for the OP Collective to track the governance "performance" of its delegates. One is for the top 100 delegates. The other is for the a16z Optimism Delegates (including university clubs, professional delegate groups, and a few crypto native delegates. They track votes participations, voting powers, voting rationales, and other relevant metrics (on both individual level and the aggregate level). It help the OP collective to identify active and inactive delegates (with lots of voting power) to reward accordingly and conduct liquid delegation when performance degrades. It also help the delegators  such as a16z's and others to know which smaller voting power delegates are active in governance: offering them a platform for delegators to know more about them.

links.name: OP Governance Tracker (General)
links.description: The Optimism Governance Dashboard provides real-time tracking of proposals and participation statistics for the Optimism Collective. By visualizing metrics like total proposals, votes cast, and voter involvement over time, the dashboard enables bi-cameral members to analyze trends and delegate activity in Optimism's on-chain governance system. It provides public accountability towards delegates with huge voting powers, identifying active ones and inactive ones and facilitating retro rewarding and liquid delegations respectively.

links.name: OP Governance Tracker (a16z Delegates)
links.description: This dashboard tracks the governance performance for a16z delegates at the Optimism Collective. It provides public accountability towards delegates with huge voting powers, identifying active ones and inactive ones and facilitating retro rewarding and liquid delegations respectively.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
- Voter turnout: delegate participation as of last update
- Non-conformity: how many delegates have their "own" opinion when voting 
- Voting Bloc power over time: tracks the top100 or individual voting power over time
- Voting Cost: total gas cost across votes and average gas cost per delegate
- Inactive Delegates: who are they and how many votes they have
- Underrated Delegates: who have little voting power but has been consistently voting and has high-non-conformity score
- Statistics on Delegate Profiling: delegates who are self delegates vs those who have more than 1 delegators

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
Professional Delegators such as a16z: to monitor performance of its delegates at OP Collective. With the dashboard that I created, they know which delegates are active and which are not contributing in governance. With the data in mind, it will facilitate liquid-delegations for their next cohort. 

OP Foundation: identify active OP delegates who are amongst the top 100 ones and conduct retro-reward for active participants accordingly. 

OP Collective Delegators: with the underrated delegate lists, they can support them by delegating OPs to these delegates and let them grow from bottom up.

Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The Lighthouse native mobile app makes it easy for Citizens and Delegates to participate in Optimism governance. We built support for Optimism's custom Governor contract, which enabled us to add multiple powerful new features:

1. We've added real time push notifications of new proposal and voting activity. 

2. We've added the ability to vote on proposals, on-chain, natively from within the Lighthouse app. 

3. We also pulled in on-chain comments and displayed them within the app, to surface community sentiment around proposals for users.

4. Our interactive Farcaster Frames integration enables on-chain proposals and comments to be shared, further increasing awareness and participation in the social media space.

This all works together to provide a powerful and feature-complete alternative client for users who wish to vote on the go.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: Token holders, delegates and followers benefit by Optimism being on Lighthouse. Even users who do not hold Optimism tokens are able to follow core Optimism proposal activity, making Optimism governance more accessible throughout the ecosystem.

name: Impact Calculator Experiment
description:
The Impact Calculator experiments with converting quantitative insights into numeric impact evaluations for Retro Funding 4 and beyond. Traditionally, voting in Retro Funding involved manually reviewing and comparing individual applications to allocate tokens, relying heavily on the experience of citizens.

We collaborated with OpenSource Observer and Jonas from Optimism Foundation to design a new method that uses quantitative data to evaluate projects, allowing voters to focus on what matters to them.

Our prototype, along with BuidlGuidl's, found practical ways to implement a voting UI and accelerate the development of a metric-based voting system for Retro Funding 4.

Governance Infrastructure::Technical infrastructure which powers the voting process within Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The Impact Calculator significantly enhanced the decision-making process for Retro Funding 4 by measuring the tangible real-world impact of each project, rather than relying on popularity metrics. This approach aligned with Optimismâ€™s mission to reward high-impact contributions to the ecosystem.

By converting raw data into quantifiable metrics, the tool enabled badgeholders to evaluate projects more objectively and efficiently, reducing assessment time while ensuring impactful projects receive recognition and funding.

Our infrastructure and tooling support Optimism Governance by providing a transparent, data-driven evaluation framework, automating impact assessments, and ensuring fair resource allocation without subjective criteriaâ€”advancing the governance goal of fostering sustainable growth.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Small builders have benefited the most from our infrastructure and tooling. They no longer need to compete with large, well-known projects for visibility. By creating impactful contributions, even on a smaller scale, they can access Retro Funding, which rewards based on real-world impact rather than recognition. This levels the playing field for those with fewer resources, enabling them to receive the funding they deserve.

Badgeholders also benefit significantly from our tooling. Weâ€™ve automated much of the data they previously had to review manually, streamlining their evaluation process. This allows them to assess projects more quickly and accurately, ensuring a fair and transparent voting process while maintaining the integrity of Optimism Governance.

name: GovXS
description:
GovXS is an initiative under Token Engineering Academy, which is a proud recipient of Optimism RetroPGF funding in Rounds 2 and 3. 

GovXS was selected to complete the Optimism Foundationâ€™s Mission Request #188â€“Evaluating Voting Design Tradeoffs for Retro Funding in June 2024. Our team of 4 experts in social choice theory, modeling and simulations, and token engineering (Nimrod Talmon, PhD, Angela Kreitenweis, Eyal Briman, and Muhammad Idrees) has now gone beyond the Mission Requestâ€™s scope to analyze actual Optimism Retro Funding voting designs and improve governance performance by proposing new, strategyproof voting rules.

**Deliverables by September 18:**

- Voting Design Mathematical Specification:
Deriving the formal specification of the exact voting rules applied in Optimismâ€™s Retro Funding Rounds 1â€“4 (R1â€“4) to allow for rigorous, axiomatic analysis

- Voting Design Evaluation Framework:
Deriving a 360Â° evaluation framework based on Optimism Retro Funding objectives

- Voting Design Evaluation Metrics:
Developing metrics to rigorously verify voting designs against Retro Funding objectives, applying theoretical, axiomatic analysis and agent-based simulations 

- Testing and Verification of Optimismâ€™s R1â€“4 Voting Rules:
Verifying if the R1â€“4 voting rules satisfy Incentive Compatibility so that voters can not improve their results by lying about their preferences (known as â€œstrategyproofnessâ€ in social choice theory)

- Detection of Major Flaws in Optimism Retro Funding:
We found major flaws in the Optimism Retro Funding voting designs (none of the R1â€“4 voting designs satisfy strategyproofness!)

- Provided 2 Strategyproof Solutions:
GovXS proposed two alternative voting designs to solve strategyproofness and meet Optimism Retro Fundingâ€™s design goals 

** Links:** 
1) Making Optimism Retro Funding Strategyproof (Report) â€“ https://mirror.xyz/0x803860D2C333734cD99625d8d189d0Eb2e565166/gvjQpafjVxAeeQnb7_Oc--5Oc7chV55zwR_NCa1_9KU

2) A Social Choice Analysis of Retroactive Funding (PDF) â€“ https://github.com/GovXS/Evaluating-Voting-Design-Tradeoffs-for-Retro-Funding/blob/main/A%20Social%20Choice%20Analysis%20of%20Retroactive%20Funding.pdf

3) GovXS Retro Funding Simulator (Open-source) â€“Â https://github.com/GovXS/Evaluating-Voting-Design-Tradeoffs-for-Retro-Funding


**Positive impact:**

- Securing Truthful Voting:
Using strategyproof voting designs ensures that voters can achieve their best results only by voting according to their true preferences. Current Retro Funding voting designs are not strategyproof. We propose alternative voting designs to solve this issue.

- Securing Expert/Guest Voter Experiments:
Optimism Retro Funding is running experiments with badgeholders, guest voters, and expert voters, investing sizably to gain insights on how to best select the most knowledgeable, value-aligned voters. These insights rely on learnings from analyzing voting data and voter preferences. If this data is skewed due to voting designs not being strategyproof, wrong conclusions will be drawn, creating negative impacts e.g. on future roundsâ€™ scope and size, or voter and project participation, hurting the entire ecosystem.

- Securing â€œImpact = Profitâ€:
Optimism's vision is to build a global system where positive impact to the collective is rewarded by profit to the individual, so that â€œImpact = Profitâ€. Retro Funding aims to find the ground truth in funding allocation. There is no instrument or algorithm yet to measure a projectâ€™s positive impact and the respective profit it deserves. Thatâ€™s why you, as a voter, are asked to assess project applications by voting in Retro Funding. If the voting rule provides voters with the wrong incentives, the results will be distorted, and Optimism Retro Funding cannot get any closer to reaching a fair, objective truth supporting â€œImpact = Profitâ€.

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
GovXS analyzed the voting designs used in Optimism Retro Funding across Rounds 1â€“4, focusing on whether voters were incentivized to truthfully report their preferences. Our analysis uncovered a critical flaw: none of the voting rules applied so far are strategyproof! 
In other words, voters can gain an advantage by not voting according to their true preferences. To fix this, we proposed two alternative voting solutions, along with clear, actionable recommendations for their implementation.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
a) **Optimism Retro Funding Program:** GovXSâ€™s advanced analytics have empowered the OP Retro Funding Program to identify and solve critical flaws and enable a strategyproof voting that upholds the integrity of retro funding.
b) **Optimism Retro Funding badgeholders, experts, and guest voters:** Badgeholders, experts and guest voters gain trust that voting outcomes reflect the true preferences of all participants.
c) **Optimism Retro Funding projects:** With GovXSâ€™s analytics-driven recommendations, Optimism Retro Funding projects have confidence in a voting process that guarantees fair compensation through transparent, objective assessments.
d) **Superchain Ecosystem:** Optimismâ€™s Retro Funding strives to achieve a true, fair allocation of rewards. Flawed voting rules distort outcomes, preventing Optimism Retro Funding from realizing its goal of aligning 'Impact = Profit.' GovXsâ€™s analysis provided actionable solutions to safeguard this vision for the long term.

name: Gravity DAO
description:
GravityDAO is an organization that develops conflict management, trust creation, and leadership as public goods. We are pioneers in promoting governance standards for web3 organizations, like mediation between peers, decentralized enforcement of graduated sanctions, and continued education on human development, strategic planning, and leadership.

We created a free online course about conflict management and trust creation in 5 languages, https://gravitydao.org/online-courses/ and we have trained many communities and individuals to transform conflict into fuel for growth. Right now we are developing content for a second free online course, focussed on the topic of leadership and strategy for Web3 projects, and we hope to publish it in the first months of 2025. 

Gravity was founded in 2021, and we have been building a reputation thanks to the years and the communities we have impacted positively with our frameworks, such as Optimism. 

We aspire to be supported in this retro funding 6 because we are working on the cutting-edge of sociotechnical systems design. The problems we tackle are the most common and shared for any project and community, so the solutions we bring are evergreen and have a wide range of impact.

grants.details: We supported the design of code of conduct enforcement solutions in season 4. After our RFP, the Code of conduct council was created in season 5, and ratified by the communty in season 6. Our processes contribute to decentralize governance from the foundation to the community.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Gravity DAO supports Optimism by designing and implementing frameworks and standards for decentralization of governance, especially in conflict management, trust creation, and leadership.

We support multiple teams in the collective with their capacity to coordinate nonviolently and transform the energy from conflicting situations into fuel for growth. 

We have facilitated alternative dispute resolution and also evergreen educational content for individuals to continue their personal and professional development. 

Our created social infrastructure and tools are replicable, conceptually robust, minimal in governance overhead, and efficient in progressive decentralization. We consider our work to be long-term impactful for the collective because we are building good practices for common needs many groups face when building towards shared goals.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Gravity DAO is a public good project. We create content that is available and accessible to anyone interested, and that is forkable and adaptative to different scenarios. The people that have benefited the most from our infrastructure and tooling are the communities that get inspired by our frameworks, like Optimism, and the students, which we call Gravitons, who have taken our training and applied the set of gained skills in their life and in their participation on groups.

Our work equips contributors with the necessary skills to participate gracefully in Web3 governance, facilitating continued improvement, informed engagement, and desired types of interaction. We develop humans and processes to foster better coordination in groups. 

We are a small team, with 5 core contributors, and over 25 occasional ones. We want to increase the reach of our message and our capacity to grow, thinking that more people can benefit from our cutting-edge work on sociotechnical systems.

subcategory: Governance facilitation of critical governance processes and/or experiments such as community calls, proposal creation or review sessions, deliberations or similar::

impactStatement.question: What governance processes or experiments did your facilitation work support and how?
impactStatement.answer:
Governance Vulnerability Discovery (Jan, 2024 - Oct 18, 2024)
During the specified time period, we uncovered and reported a significant governance vulnerability related to voting power discrepancies within the Optimism governance framework. 

Vulnerability Identification
In August 2024, we discovered a critical issue where certain addresses had disproportionately high voting power, exceeding their actual token holdings. This created the risk of skewing governance decisions and breaking the "one token, one vote" principle, which is foundational to decentralized governance. There was >200,000 OP which were double voted.
The vulnerability allows certain addresses to retain voting power for >200,000 OP even after selling the tokens, effectively doubling their influence. They could split their holdings to create multiple top 100 delegate spots for 0 token cost, further increasing their power, posing a zero-cost attack risk.

impactStatement.question: How has your facilitation work improved the performance of the governance process or experiment?
impactStatement.answer:
The vulnerability was reported promptly to the Optimism governance team, ensuring that the issue was addressed before it could materially impact governance outcomes in future voting cycles.

Collaborative Resolution
After reporting the issue, we worked with the Optimism team to clarify the problem and assist in formulating a fix. 
The governance team implemented a fix that removed the inflated delegations and prevented such issues from happening in future voting cycles.
The prompt resolution and transparency around the issue maintained the integrity of the OP governance system
Token House and RetroPGF Consideration
This discovery did not fall under a formal bounty program or RetroPGF framework, the Optimism governance team acknowledged the importance of the contribution and allowed for RPGF. This recognition emphasized the value of community-driven governance security efforts, even in the absence of formalized bounty structures.

name: Fracton Research - Retrospective Quantitative Review of Grants
description:
This research aims to improve governance by achieving more effective public goods funding through the comparison of various grant models. Grant programs play a crucial role in the crypto ecosystem, but comparative studies are rare. In this study, we compare different types of programs such as Uniswap, dYdX, Optimism, and Gitcoin, categorizing them into "top-down," "bottom-up," and "QF (algorithmic)" types. Our findings suggest that bottom-up and QF types tend to distribute funds more evenly, with smaller grant amounts and less variability, while top-down types exhibit greater variability and tend to provide larger grants to fewer recipients.

The goal of this research is to achieve a more effective and fair grants program. We aim to uncover the differences among various grant programs and provide insights that could improve future program management. By conducting a cross-comparative quantitative analysis, focusing especially on decision-making bodies, we investigated how grant amounts and the number of grants are influenced by different types of decision-making mechanisms. Looking ahead, we plan to develop tools for impact evaluation, impact measurement, or outcome measurement based on these results. This will enable evidence-based public goods funding by using grants data, ensuring that future grants are more effective and aligned with measurable outcomes.

This research and development includes Optimism Collective as a subject of investigation, focusing on identifying the unique characteristics of the Optimism Collective, analyzing the current state of its fund distribution, and comparing it with other grant programs. This approach will contribute to designing more effective, evidence-based funding strategies and to realizing the vision of Retro Funding.

links.name: A Retrospective Quantitative Review of Crypto Grants Programs
links.description:
In this survey, I quantitatively compared grant amounts among the programs implemented by Uniswap, dYdX, Optimism, and Gitcoin to find the differences among them. This survey revealed trends based on the characteristics of the grants programs managers (decision-makers). In Uniswap and dYdX, the grants programs are operated by a few arbitrarily selected individuals (top-down type), Optimism is managed by individuals elected or selected based on objective criteria (bottom-up type), and Gitcoin uses a direct democratic method called Quadratic Funding (QF type) where decisions are made by a large number of people. The hypothesis that could be drawn from categorizing these operations is that there is a correlation with the amount of grants. The bottom-up and QF types tend to distribute funds more evenly with smaller variability and smaller grant amounts. Conversely, the top-down type shows greater variability in the amounts received by each grantee, and fewer recipients in general. This means that while bottom-up and QF types distribute grants more evenly, providing a sort of economic infrastructure, the top-down type shows a kind of bias with a greater variability in grant amounts, with fewer recipients receiving larger. This suggests that bottom-up and QF types tend to fund projects with high public utility, whereas top-down types are more likely to fund projects that benefit their own protocols, reflecting a fundamental difference in the underlying motivations of each grants program.

However, while the bias introduced by top-down grants may seem negative from a fairness perspective, I consider this bias important. This aligns with traditional economic theory, where governments intervene to provide goods that are difficult to manage in the market. Top-down granters can play a role similar to government intervention, providing funds for projects that fall outside the scope of QF, potentially introducing serendipity in the public goods market. Therefore, the bias in top-down grants programs may bring positive outcomes when viewed from the ecosystem as a whole. There may be a need for environments that produce diverse grants programs aiming to provide public goods based on certain or biased values. At the same time, funding "outliers" needs feedback and accountability from the grantee to the grantor, or this means the importance of funding systems based on project outcomes, though general grants programs need too. In the future, measuring the outcomes of grantees can help grantors focus on the types of projects that are most beneficial. Organizations like Venture Grantor, as well as VCs and foundations focused on the provision and maintenance of public goods, will also value this role.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer: Our analysis identifies the characteristics of the fund distribution methods used in the Optimism Collectiveâ€™s grant programs by comparing them with other grant programs. We analyze distribution patterns, such as the size of grants, the number of recipients, decision-making processes, and how evenly resources are allocated, highlighting how Optimismâ€™s fund distribution differs from other governance models. We have found that Optimism provides relatively larger grants, supports a greater number of recipients, and shows less variation in the amount granted per recipient. We also examine how effective Optimismâ€™s governance structure is in promoting fair and impactful public goods funding. Additionally, we expect this analysis to lead to the proposal of new types of grants and the measurement and evaluation of impact based on data, contributing to more effective funding practices.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer: The main beneficiaries of our analytical work are decision-makers involved in Optimism Collectiveâ€™s grant distribution, as well as those looking to improve grant allocation models and governance mechanisms. By providing insights into fund distribution patterns and the effectiveness of different governance mechanisms, we support these stakeholders in making evidence-based decisions. This will enable the Optimism Collective to contribute to the Optimism ecosystem, the Ethereum ecosystem, and real-world public goods, making true public goods funding a reality through evidence-based decision-making. Our research helps contributors make informed decisions.

name: Tribuni Telegram Bot
description:
Who We Are

Tribuni was born out of the ETH Denver hackathon, spearheaded by a team of decentralized governance practitioners. Our founding members include delegates from Blockchain@USC actively participating in Optimism's governance. With expertise spanning software engineering, product design, and product management across both Web2 and crypto landscapes, our diverse team is dedicated to enhancing the delegate experience.

Our Story

Being a delegate requires constantly staying up-to-date due to the sheer volume of information that needs to be digested. Before Tribuni, we experienced firsthand the challenges of managing extensive data and keeping track of vital governance activities. To address this pain point, we engaged with a wide range of delegates from groups such as 404DAO, Brichis, PGov, Launamu, FranklinDAO, etc. Their insights and feedback inspired us to build a tool tailored specifically for delegates like them.

Our Solution

Delegates are the cornerstone of Optimism's governance system. Active and well-informed delegates lead to resilient and sound governance. However, delegates need to process a lot of information and often find it challenging to stay up-to-date. We are humans after all.

To help delegates stay active and well-informed, our team launched Tribuniâ€”a free Telegram mini-app built exclusively for delegates. Tribuni sends quality AI-generated proposal summaries, vote reminders, and OP forum activity digests directly via Telegram. This ensures that delegates never miss a vote or an important discussion within the OP ecosystem, as long as they're connected to Telegram.

Impact

As of September 2024, Tribuni proudly supports 28 OP delegate profiles, encompassing a staggering 28,217,127 votes combined. This substantial vote power not only surpasses Optimism's 26 million quorum but also underscores Tribuni's pivotal role in the governance ecosystem. Our platform serves 38 dedicated Optimism subscribers, including influential entities like PGOV, blockchain@USC, 404DAO, PGov, Gauntlet, Tane Gov, etc who manage multiple delegate memberships. Through Tribuni, we help them analyzed 1,113 posts across 186 forum topics, ensuring they remain well-informed and proactive in decision-making. By seamlessly integrating into their workflows, Tribuni has become an indispensable tool, empowering delegates to govern more effectively and maintain the resilience of Optimism's governance structure.

name: Superchain Attestation Explorer
description:
Attestation explorer for the Superchain Optimism.
Built on Ethereum Attestation Service (EAS) with a more streamlined UX and a focus on Superchain attestations.
Enhances transparency and trust for the reputation of people and projects.

The Superchain Attestation Explorer is a powerful tool designed to enhance transparency and trust within the Optimism ecosystem by allowing users to explore attestations relevant to Optimism governance. Built on the Ethereum Attestation Service (EAS), the explorer streamlines the user experience and focuses on Superchain attestations. It serves as a critical infrastructure for understanding and verifying the reputations of individuals and projects, supporting the Optimism Collective's long-term goals of decentralization, trust, and governance participation.

By providing a seamless and intuitive interface, the Superchain Attestation Explorer improves access to essential governance data, enabling Optimism citizens and delegates to participate more effectively in governance processes such as Retro Funding. The explorer aims to make the attestation data more accessible, offering new features like leaderboards, badges, and enhanced profile views to increase community engagement and improve decision-making based on verifiable reputation.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The Superchain Attestation Explorer provides a user-friendly and accessible way to review and verify user reputations. While existing EAS attestation explorers present raw data, the Superchain Attestation Explorer refines this by focusing on the most useful attestation services for OP governance.

Displaying key attestation data in a more digestible format allows badgeholders & delegates to evaluate contributions and trustworthiness within the ecosystem efficiently, enhancing decision-making during critical governance processes like RetroFunding.

Praise Discord Bot
Regen Score
Optimist
Passport Score
Praise on Farcaster
Coordinape
DeVouch
Metrics Garden

The explorer showcases these eight core attestation services, including six on OP Mainnet and two on Base. This integration across multiple chains positions the explorer as a Superchain attestation tool, reinforcing its role as an essential infrastructure.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The primary beneficiaries of the Superchain Attestation Explorer are governance participants involved in the Retro Funding process. Specifically, OP Citizens and delegates that rely on the tool to efficiently review user reputations and contributions within the Optimism ecosystem. 

By offering a more readable interface than raw data explorers like EAS, the Attestation Explorer helps these participants make more informed decisions during governance activities.

In addition, the tool helps Retro Funding voters better assess contributors' impact and credibility, ensuring that governance rewards are distributed based on verified, high-quality contributions. 
The broader Superchain community also benefits from easier cross-chain attestation visibility.
