impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Gitcoin developed the voting interfaces for Retrofunding 4 & Retrofunding 5, which were used by badgeholders to allocate funds during those rounds. We worked closely with Agora, who powered the API, and Optimism, who outlined the requirements and provided designs.

For RF4, we worked closely with Open Source Observer and Optimism to implement new metrics-based discovery, selection, and weighting. Our solution allowed users to filter and evaluate projects based on various impact metrics. 

For both RF 4 & RF5, we created a user-friendly interface for governance participants to allocate their votes. 

These tools are primarily used within Optimism Governance to support the Retroactive Public Goods Funding process, which is a crucial part of Optimism's governance model. They aim to make the process of discovering, evaluating, and voting for projects more efficient, transparent, and user-friendly for governance participants.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The direct benefits are the Optimism badgeholders and recipients of Retrofunding. During RF4, 108 out of 133 badgeholders participated. $10M OP tokens were allocated to 207 projects. 

Though RF5 is still ongoing at the time of this application, participation is high. Badgeholders are expected to allocate between 2-8m OP tokens to up to 89 projects.

The team has also integrated these features into EasyRetroPGF.xyz, which makes them available to a wider range of users involved in Optimism's governance processes. The SUNNYS Awards have also been built on this same technology!

name: GovNERDs [Season 5]
description: GovNERDs is a program designed to improve governance accessibility within the Optimism Collective. We guide proposals through critical stages like feedback, approval, and voting, ensuring that governance processes are transparent and efficient. By taking on key administrative responsibilities, govNERDs have significantly reduced the Foundation's workload, enabling a smoother and more decentralized governance approach. Our success in Season 5 paved the way for the program's transition to an open contribution path in Season 6, encouraging broader community participation.

grants.details: The govNERDs received 40,500 OP (13,500 OP per govNERD) with a one-year lock.

We also manage onboarding hubs for both Token House and Citizens' House, ensuring participants have the support they need to engage effectively. Additionally, we provide forum moderation, ensuring that governance discussions remain high-quality and focused.

name: RetroList
description:
RetroList is a project discovery platform for Retro Funding, covering rounds 3 to 6 of OP Retro Funding.

RetroList also offers detailed analytics for each round, including:
- Project reward distribution across different reward groups
- Project reward distribution by category
- Public crowdsourcing lists for RetroPGF 3
- Metrics distribution for Retro Funding 4
- Open-source vs. closed-source project distribution for Retro Funding 4
- Project reward breakdown by impact metrics for Retro Funding 4

Additionally, RetroList provides an API for projects to query data. Our API is typically launched a few days after the signup period and maintains a stable schema.

The RetroList API is currently used by DeVouch and Impact Garden.

For more information about the RetroList API, please contact @chomtana on Telegram.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
RetroList, a project discovery platform for OP Retro Funding, significantly supports Optimism governance by providing detailed analytics and accessible data across Retro Funding rounds 3 to 6.

RetroList also offers detailed analytics for each round, including:
- Project reward distribution across different reward groups
- Project reward distribution by category
- Public crowdsourcing lists for RetroPGF 3
- Metrics distribution for Retro Funding 4
- Open-source vs. closed-source project distribution for Retro Funding 4
- Project reward breakdown by impact metrics for Retro Funding 4

Additionally, RetroList has provided an API that enables direct data queries by other projects like DeVouch and Impact Garden.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Every stakeholder in the Retro Funding process benefits from RetroList, including:
- Any user can discover Retro Funding projects and get inspiration to build on the Superchain.
- Project owners have a UI to check if their project has gone through correctly.
- Badgeholders, delegates, and the OP Foundation have access to the RetroList analytics, which has an impact on badgeholders' voting decisions and the design of future Retro Funding rounds.
- Ecosystem projects have access to the API for querying project data within a few days after the sign-up period and maintain a stable schema.

The RetroList API has been used internally by the DeVouch and Impact Garden projects.

name: Cantina.xyz - OP Stack
description:
Cantina.xyz is a marketplace incubated by Spearbit Labs, bringing together over 100 experienced security professionals and teams. We provide a wide range of code review and audit services to web3 clients, aiming to fortify the blockchain ecosystem. Our mission is to deliver top-tier security audits, continuous monitoring, advisory, and incident response services, ensuring organizationsâ€™ smart contracts and systems are thoroughly secured before deployment.


We have an established track record within the Optimism ecosystem, having successfully conducted multiple audits, including those for the OP Stack. Our services align closely with Optimismâ€™s goals by providing essential, high-quality security auditing and incident response solutions.

ventureFunding.details: Seed funding we received.

pricingModelDetails:
Our tiers of security researchers (SR) and rates are as it follows:

Lead Security Researcher, weekly rate: $20k
Security Researcher, weekly rate: $12.5k
Associate Security Researcher, weekly rate: $6.25k
Junior Security Researcher, weekly rate: $3k

links.name: OP Stack Audit 1
links.description:
We conducted a security audit for the OP Stack. The audit was carried out between January 22, 2024, and February 5, 2024, by two primary security researchers, cccz and Jeiwan, along with an associate researcher, Christos Pap. The audit did not uncover any critical, high, or medium-risk vulnerabilities. However, seven low-risk and seven informational issues were identified. None of these issues were fixed, but the team acknowledged all.

The audit also evaluated gas optimizations, and no concerns were noted.

Key Audit Results:

    Critical Risk: 0 issues
    High Risk: 0 issues
    Medium Risk: 0 issues
    Low Risk: 7 issues (acknowledged, not fixed)
    Informational: 7 issues (acknowledged, not fixed)
    Gas Optimizations: No issues

We can provide the report upon request.

links.name: Optimism EAS Audit
links.description:
We conducted a security audit for Optimismâ€™s EAS. From August 22 to August 25, 2023. This audit, categorized under Cantina Reviews, was led by the senior security researcher 0xRajeev, with junior researcher Christos Pap assisting.

The audit found no critical, high, or medium-risk vulnerabilities. However, it uncovered five low-risk issues, of which two were fixed, and three were acknowledged. Additionally, five informational issues were identified, with four being fixed and one acknowledged. Importantly, five gas optimization opportunities were highlighted, and all were addressed and fixed.

Key Audit Results:
Critical Risk: 0 issues
High Risk: 0 issues
Medium Risk: 0 issues
Low Risk: 5 issues (2 fixed, 3 acknowledged)
Informational: 5 issues (4 fixed, 1 acknowledged)
Gas Optimizations: 5 issues (all fixed)

We can provide the report upon request.

links.name: Optimism Safe Extensions Competition
links.description:
Cantina.xyz participated in and was awarded in the Optimism Safe Extensions competition. This competition, held between May 6, 2024, and May 10, 2024, focused on reviewing the security of Safe Modules and the Safe Guard for the Security Council Safe, which handles upgrades to OP Mainnet and other chains within the Superchain.

Our participation involved analyzing key components like the LivenessModule, LivenessGuard, and DeputyGuardianModule, deployed on Sepolia. Our review contributed to ensuring that these critical systems were free from vulnerabilities such as:

    Bypassing authorization.
    Bricking the Safe, which could prevent transaction execution.

We can provide the report upon request.

links.name: Optimism Drippie Security Review
links.description:
The Optimism Drippie Security Review, carried out in October 2022, focused on auditing Drippie, a system designed to manage automated contract interactions. Drippie allows for conditional, automated execution of smart contract calls, referred to as "drips." These can be triggered based on specific conditions (called "dripchecks") and executed at set intervals. Drips can also transfer ETH, making the system useful for maintaining sufficient balances in addresses. The review specifically focused on ensuring the security of the system without reliance on external automation services, thus compartmentalizing trust assumptions.

Findings:

    Medium Risk:
        Permitting Multiple Drip Calls Per Block: This vulnerability could potentially allow multiple drips to be executed within the same block, which was flagged as a security risk.

    Low Risk:
        Version Bump to Latest: The code was using outdated versions, and upgrading was recommended.
        DoS from External Calls in Drippie.executable / Drippie.drip: External calls could be used to perform a denial-of-service attack.
        Use call.value over transfer in withdrawETH: For better handling of ETH transfers, the use of call.value was recommended over transfer.
        Input Validation Checks for Drippie.create: The lack of proper input validation could lead to unexpected behaviors.
        Ownership Initialization and Transfer Safety in setOwner: Recommendations were made to improve safety checks when initializing and transferring ownership.
        Unchecked Return and Handling of Non-standard Tokens in AssetReceiver: The contract didnâ€™t adequately handle non-standard token behaviors.

links.name: Security Audit for Omni-x
links.description: The audit for Omni-x focused on reviewing the security of the Omni X Multisender, an omnichain gas top-up tool built for the Optimism ecosystem. This tool allows users to send gas between OP Stack chains and other EVM-compatible chains using LayerZero v2, promoting more efficient gas fee management. The audit ensures the systemâ€™s robustness as Omni X expands its infrastructure, improving cross-chain interactions within Optimism. The audit scope was small, involving a 2-3 day engagement to ensure security before the mainnet launch.

links.name: Security Audit for Decent.xyz
links.description: For Decent.xyz we focused on securing its cross-chain transaction and swap protocols, enabling seamless transfers across L2s, L3s, and the broader OP stack. Decent.xyz provides an efficient way for users to swap tokens while executing smart contract functions, reducing friction in cross-chain interactions. The audit enhanced the project's safety and scalability.

subcategory: Security audits specifically on the OP Stack or its components.

impactStatement.question: How has your project advanced the development of the OP Stack?
impactStatement.answer:
Cantina/Spearbit has advanced the development of the OP Stack by providing critical security audits and reviews to ensure the robustness and safety of its components. Our team has conducted multiple audits of the OP Stack, including security reviews of Optimism's EAS, which are crucial for cross-chain functionality and gas optimization. Through these audits, we have identified vulnerabilities, suggested optimizations, and collaborated with Optimism team to ensure that the OP Stack is secure and resilient.

Additionally, our continuous monitoring, advisory services, and incident response support help maintain the OP Stack's reliability, safeguarding its smart contracts and infrastructure.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited the most from your work on the OP Stack and how?
impactStatement.answer:
The primary beneficiaries of our work on the OP Stack have been developers and projects building within the Optimism ecosystem, as well as the broader Optimism community. By conducting thorough security audits, we have ensured that developers can deploy secure smart contracts, reducing the risk of exploits and vulnerabilities.

Projects like Omni-x and Decent.xyz, which rely on cross-chain capabilities and transaction efficiency, have directly benefited from our security reviews, enabling them to operate safely and scale their solutions across multiple chains.

Our work has enhanced trust and reliability in the OP Stack, making it safer for both developers and users.

name: Collective Feedback Commission Citizens House
description:
We are the Citizens House Feedback Commission, a group of 9 high context individuals selected by the Optimism Foundation to provide high context feedback on early design and communication drafts related to the RetroRounds. 

We provide detailed actionable feedback, poke holes at the design, and give recommendations for the Foundation to modify and improve the design, execution and processes of experiments related to the RetroRounds and lately also for Optimismâ€™s Decentralization and Product Vision.

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The mandate of the Citizens House Collective Feedback Commission (CFC) is to formalize the process of gathering hight-context feedback from highly engaged Citizens during the design phase of RetroRounds in multiple levels and stages of the process. In the initial scope, members were expected to spend an average of 5 hours per Round/Season providing feedback, with work starting on April 1st for 6 months where feedback would be provided for Rounds 4 and 5 only.  

The work developed by the Citizens House Feedback Commission marks a significant step towards setting the foundations for the decentralization of the metagovernance design process.

More information on the initial scope of work for the Commission can be found here: 
- Introducing the Collective Feedback Commission
https://gov.optimism.io/t/introducing-the-collective-feedback-commission/7863 
- The Path to Open Metagovernance
https://gov.optimism.io/t/the-path-to-open-metagovernance/7728

The Citizenâ€™s FC achieved it's mandate and initial scope of work by providing feedback to 8 documents for Rounds 4 and 5.

Additionally, we exceeded our mandate by crafting the proposal of a Mission Request, providing feedback for Optimismâ€™s Decentralization Milestones, Optimismâ€™s Product Vision, Backstopped Grants and Round 6; extending our work into early October.
Feedback led to:
1. Changes in the scope of Round 6 and itâ€™s sub-categories
2. Increase in the resources provided by the Foundation for context setting for the Decentralization Milestones such as: explainer post, loom video, additional frameworks.
3. Feedback on the Product Vision led to â€œmoderate editsâ€ and was â€œvery usefulâ€ to demonstrate opportunity areas in the communications from the Foundation.

Based on the impact generated, the Commission will become a permanent structure:
https://bit.ly/4h6CJs7

Reward split:

name: Flexy
description:
Flexy offers DeFi users a cost-free way to obtain tokens and gas on various networks. At its core, Flexy works as a cross-chain bridge that can deliver specific ERC20s and gas in a single, gasless transaction. Flexy is a public good that offers completely free bridging for stablecoins across OP stack L2s. Flexy currently charges a minimal 0.1% fee for non-stablecoin transfers to offset operational costs (liquidity provisioning), though we aim to offer fully-free transfers for all tokens, subsidized by retrofunding.

Utilizing EIP-2612, users need only sign a single off-chain signature to initiate a bridge transaction, reducing user friction and abstracting away crypto complexities. All values are denominated in USD to make value transfer clear and easy to understand.

Flexy can be integrated into any dApp via the Flexy widget, installable via npm. The Flexy widget allows projects across DeFi to add a tailored cross-chain bridge directly into their own dApp to deliver ERC20s and gas that users need to interact with the contracts on their supported chains.

github.name: Flexy Contracts and Published Audits
github.description: This repo contains the smart contracts that power Flexy, including V1 and V2 which were previously called Gasbot. Audit reports for Flexy and Gasbot are also contained in the /audit subdirectory.

github.name: Flexy Demo Integrations
github.description: This repo provides multiple examples on how to integrate a Flexy widget into a dApp. Examples show how to use various web3 libraries like Ethers, Wagmi, Web3-react and also provide support for various vanilla forks like Uniswap, PancakeSwap, and GMX.

pricingModelDetails: We offer completely free bridging across OP stack L2s for all stablecoin transfers. We charge a 0.1% fee for non-stablecoin transfers to offset operation costs (i.e. liquidity provisioning), however, Flexy makes no profit in the process. We are a public good to offer seamless bridging at a fraction of the cost of other bridging providers.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Flexy offers superchain users the easiest and cheapest way to acquire $OP for use in governance. For the past year, users were able to acquire $OP through gasless transactions via a single off-chain signature, offering the easiest method for obtaining $OP cross-chain.

Users who obtained $OP via Flexy saved large amounts in bridge fees, as Flexy is dedicated to providing bridging as a public good. We aim to receive grant funding to offer fully-free $OP acquisition, with Flexy operational costs being fully offset by retro funding.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
- $OP governance token holders. These users were able to save time and money by using our dedicated $OP token bridge. https://www.flexy.tech/bridge?chainId=10&outputToken=0x4200000000000000000000000000000000000042

- OP stack projects. dApps live on OP stack chains were able to integrate the Flexy widget to provide their users the ability to obtains $OP directly from the dApp itself utilizing a shared wallet connection. We were able to save users time and headache when obtaining their $OP for governance voting or delegation.

name: Metagov's Overall Activities
description:
Metagov is a nonprofit focused on researching governance in the context of digital communities. The mission of Metagov is to cultivate tools, practices, and communities that enable self-governance in the digital age. Metagov works toward a governance layer for the internet that is empowering, creative, interconnected, and accountable. 

We hosted side events at ETH Denver and ETH CC that brought together folks from the superchain ecosystem. 

Other projects at Metagov include KOI Pond, Gateway, Govbase, Governance Archeology, and others. Learn more on our website: https://metagov.org/.

links.name: Deliberative Tooling Interoperability Project
links.description: This project had multiple aspects to it, that include 1) running an RFP for deliberative tooling projects to specifically fund the development of interoperability features, and 2) hiring a senior engineer to support the cohort. One of the projects that received a grant is active in the Optimism ecosystem.

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer: While Metagov's general project have not been specifically focused on Optimism's governance, we have had a variety of projects meant to help advance governance in digital communities. From projects like Exit to Community and the Open Source transition calculator (exploring the costs of governance transitions and actualizing progressive decentralization) to projects like KOI Pond (using LLMs to increase sense making), Metagov is exploring research and tools that have a lot of relevant to Optimism and other DAOs/

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer: Our work is generally consumed by those who are researching, studying or building systems pertaining to governance. Our community involves those interested in DAOs, coops, commons, and open source projects. The information is open to all and meant to help people enact governance systems that empower individuals and communities.

name: Anticapture Commission [Season 6]
description: The Anticapture Commission Season 6 is a metagovernance structure comprising high context delegates, designed to prevent capture of the Token House by any single entity. The Anticapture Commission Season 6 was initiated at the start of Season 6 of Governance, and is a continuation of Anticapture Commission Season 5, with few changes among the delegates who are part of the ACC for Season 6. The Anticapture Commission has been delegated 10M OP from the Governance Fund, and votes on upgrade proposals in the Token House, along with advocating for decentralization across the Optimism stack.

grants.details:
ACC S5 members received Retro Governance Rewards of 4,000 OP per Delegate, totaling 39,400 OP across all Delegates for maintaining voting participation.

For ACC S6, there have not been any reward as of date, but similar Retro Governance Participation Rewards are expected.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 6: May 9th - September 18th 2024 (up until Voting Cycle #28)

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
The Anticapture Commission (ACC) was created to prevent capture of the Token House by any single tokenholder or group, including protocols and OP Chains. It represents high-impact individual delegates and acts as a communication bridge between the Token House and Citizens' House, addressing imbalances in power and maintaining governance integrity.
 
Relevant Documentation:
Anticapture Commission Mandate: https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission/6889

Anticapture Commission Communication Thread:  https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-communication-thread/7501/9


Season 6 Internal Operating Procedures: https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-s6-internal-operating-procedures-iop/8637

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
During S6 Governance (VC #25 to #28), ACC voted on the Dolomite Network upgrade proposal. ACC held discussions and shared feedback to the Foundation on the Dolomite Upgrade Proposal on certain technical aspects of the upgrade that the ACC members felt could have been better implemented. (Reference: https://gov.optimism.io/t/anticapture-commission-communication-thread/7501/20 ) 

During S6 voting cycles, few Delegates encountered voting issues on the Agora UI, resulting in wrongly cast votes during a mission request vote. The ACC held internal discussions on the issue and took it up with the Agora team and worked towards resolving the issue. 


The ACC also held a call to discuss the Accelerated Decentralization Proposal for Optimism with GFX Labs and the Foundation. (Reference: https://gov.optimism.io/t/accelerated-decentralization-proposal-for-optimism/8875/32 ) 
 
Since the Start of Season 6 of Governance, votable supply has increased by 7.31%, from 89.4m OP to 96m OP.
